title_oics: Delivery of climate services through Rwanda’s national agricultural extension service extended to 106,000 farmers, and deepened through climate service Radio Listening Clubs
title_project: Climate Services for Agriculture: Empowering Farmers to Manage Risk and Adapt to a Changing Climate in Rwanda
outcome_impact_statement: Rwanda Climate Services for Agriculture supported the Twigire Muhinzi agricultural extension service to scale up Participatory Integrated Climate Services for Agriculture (PICSA) in 27 of Rwanda’s 30 districts, facilitating 106,000 Rwandan farmers to understand and act on climate information.  Climate service delivery was deepened through the launch of 225 Radio Listening Clubs that convene PICSA participant farmers to listen to and discuss biweekly climate services radio broadcasts, take turns participating in call-in shows, and provide input to future programming content.

title_oics: Ghana's COCBOD incorporates CGIAR science into training materials for climate resilient cocoa production (targeting a potential 800,000 farmers)
title_project: Mainstreaming CSA practices in mixed tree/food crop systems among smallholder farmers in W Africa & Latin America
scope_comments: Potential for expansion into Ivory Coast of these findings exist.
outcome_impact_statement: The Ghanaian cocoa sector made important strides towards climate-resilience under COCOBOD leadership. Exposure maps were combined with exposure gradient specific CSA practices in a national training manual of obligatory use for all public and private extension targeting the 800,000 cocoa farmers in the country.  Additional CSA specific training materials were developed with World Cocoa Foundation which enabled the establishment of 4 pilots are on-going with private sector actors to study how to incentivize CSA uptake by farmers.

title_oics: Enhancing the impacts of Egypt's national cash transfer program for the very poor
title_project: 4.1.2 Improving Design and Delivery of Social protection for Nutrition and Other Outcomes
outcome_impact_statement: Lessons from the impact evaluation of Egypt’s cash transfer "Takaful and Karama" program conducted by PIM contributed to the decision of the Government of Egypt to continue to fund this program and to the World Bank's decision to continue to support it. The Government of Egypt adopted several recommendations from the evaluation, including on how to improve targeting by increasing awareness about the program among the very poor.

title_oics: Analysis and collaboration lays the foundation for food system improvements in Ethiopia
title_project: Methods, metrics and tools for assessing and analyzing diet-food system linkages
outcome_impact_statement: The first step toward identifying ways to improve something is to understand the current situation. In 2018, A4NH researchers completed an in-depth analysis of Ethiopian food systems to determine what and where research is needed. This has evolved into a food systems research agenda for Ethiopia. In 2018, Flagship 1 researchers with national stakeholders started implementing the agenda through activities like development of food based dietary guidelines and embedding evidence-based activities in efforts to operationalize the National Nutrition-Sensitive Agriculture Strategy.

title_oics: Building a theoretical basis and public support for nutrition sensitive value chains
title_project: Methods, metrics and tools for assessing and analyzing diet-food system linkages
scope_comments: Scope is both global in nature and multinational. Specific adaptions and applications known (so far) include Burkina Faso, Malawi, Indonesia, and Nigeria.
outcome_impact_statement: In Phase I, A4NH researchers with partners developed a framework for considering how and whether to invest in nutrition-sensitive value chains. Since then, the framework has been endorsed by the Global Forum on Food Security and Nutrition and adapted and applied by several Rome-based agencies. This updated outcome story describes how the framework has been adapted into practical guidance, published by the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD), for those interested in designing nutrition-sensitive value chain projects.

title_oics: Busia County Biodiversity Policy (Kenya) recognizes importance of native species for nutrition and food security and allocates resources for the conservation of regional food biodiversity
title_project: Policy process analysis and policy engagement
scope_comments:
Busia County, Kenya
Other counties in Kenya and Ethiopia, Uganda and Tanzania
outcome_impact_statement: Innovative multi-sectoral policy platforms bring together the environment, agriculture and health sectors, in some countries, for the first time. In Kenya, a multi-disciplinary team of farmer organizations, non-governmental organizations, and national and international government agencies have successfully promoted best practices and pilot programs around biodiversity. Outcomes include: increasing interest in nutritious African leafy vegetables; the pilot-testing of a food procurement approach that links local producers to schools and health clinics; and the endorsement of a first-of-its-kind biodiversity conservation policy.

title_oics: Randomized Control Trials on ICT advisory applications (SSNM), and testing the role of reinforcement messages.
Heat and drought-resistant wheat varieties in Pakistan help farmers combat climate change stress and is success of physiological breeding approach
scope_comments: Innovation and outcome is relevant to all increasingly heat/drought-prone wheat-producing regions in South Asia.
outcome_impact_statement: The stress of climate change on wheat production means farmers urgently need more heat and drought tolerant varieties. An innovative approach by WHEAT scientists, combining genetic diversity with physiological and molecular breeding and bio-informatic technologies, has resulted in several successful outcomes, including three lines of wheat varieties specifically bred for increased tolerance to heat and drought in Pakistan. The Pakistan Agricultural Research Council has taken on certified seed multiplication more than 100,000 Pakistani farmers currently grow one or more of the 3 varieties.

title_oics: International Wheat Blast Consortium convened by WHEAT achieves early successes: Bundled research, resistant varieties in South Asia
scope_comments: India, Pakistan and possibly other South Asian countries affected in the near future.
outcome_impact_statement: Since the discovery of wheat blast in Bangladesh in 2016, WHEAT, led by pathologist Pawan Singh, has coordinated 13+ partners to deliver a rapid response to mitigate the threat of the fungal disease in the region, which puts 7 million hectares of wheat growing area at risk in Bangladesh, India and Pakistan, according to a WHEAT 2018 ex-ante analysis (yield losses worth US$264M). A multi-pronged approach (regional convening, fundraising, education, release of resistant varieties) has led to initial outcomes.

title_oics: 15 million Euro invested for mitigation action in Thailand's rice sector
title_project: Assessing incentives for scaling up mitigation at different stakeholder levels: 'No-regret' mitigation strategies in rice production
scope_comments: The project is being implemented in the central plains of Thailand but will have additional impact in other areas in Thailand.
outcome_impact_statement: The NAMA Facility has approved the EUR 14,900,000 Thai Rice NAMA project. Implementing the project is the consortium of Thai Rice Department (TRD), GIZ, IRRI, SRP, and other rice-based public/private partners. The project builds on IRRI/CCAFS science on 4 different low-emission development technologies and targets to reach 100,000 rice farmers in 6 provinces. The expected 21.5mio Euro additional direct financial investments from the private sector and 9mio Euro in kind contribution from TRD leverage fund requirement towards better project implementation.

title_oics: Uptake and impact of Climate Smart Agriculture on food security, incomes and assets in East Africa
title_project: RPL EA: Regional and national engagement, synthesis and strategic research
scope_comments: Adoption is examined across multiple location - Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania, and impact assessment uses Nyando in Western Kenya as the case study.

title_oics: 600,000 hectares of rice planted earlier in Vietnam to avoid risk to salinity intrusion brought by the 2019 El Nino
title_project: [Regional Program Leader] SEA: Regional/National synthesis, engagement and support
outcome_impact_statement: Based on directives issued by the MARD Vice Minister and the Department of Crop Production (DCP), the rice planting calendar in the Mekong River Delta(MRD) was adjusted to avoid salinity intrusion brought by the 2019 El Nino.  The adjustments covering more than 600,000 hectares(Novemebr 2018 early planting reached 802,702 ha from 174,538 ha in 2017 and the December to February planting went down to 596,543 from 1,226,961 ha) were guided by climate-risk related maps and adaptation plans(CS-MAP) developed for the 13 provinces.

title_oics: G7 Development Ministers' Meeting News Release
title_project: [Gender and Social Inclusion] GSI: Engagement, synthesis and support in Gender

title_oics: Is a distributed research program an effective model for implementing R4D? Researchers need to collaborate to address grand challenges such as climate change, poverty and sustainable food production. This study investigates how the researchers in a globally distributed research program (CCAFS) interact to move their research forward
title_project: [Flagship Leader] FP1: Engagement, synthesis and support
scope_comments: This study is (in essence) an evaluation of how FP1 functions as a distributed research program. Some of the evaluation will be relevant for other CCAFS flagships too.

title_oics: Inputs on Land Productivity for the Long-Term Green Growth Policy of Colombia
title_project: [Regional Program Leader] LAM: Local to National/Regional synthesis, research and engagement
outcome_impact_statement: CCAFS-CIAT consortium provided technical and policy recommendations on Land Productivity and Agricultural Performance for the Colombian Green Growth Policy, which was launched in July 2018. Current National Development Plan states the focus on financial instruments for sustainable agricultural activities that include climate-smart innovation processes and technologies in line with the Green-Growth-Policy. The goal is to increase by 3%, the agricultural production share under green-growth criteria. CCAFS is supporting policy implementation through technical support in developing the indicator for agricultural production.

title_oics: Community Seed Banks in Nepal. Proceedings of the 2nd National Workshop, 3-5 May 2018, Kathmandu.
title_project: Global policy support for biologically diverse, climate resilient agriculture

title_oics: Building resilience through joint village land use planning in Tanzania
title_project: 5.1.1 Enhancing Tenure Security
outcome_impact_statement: Through the Sustainable Rangeland Management Project supported by PIM and Livestock, joint village land use planning has been implemented in three areas in the Kiketo District in rural Tanzania, securing 150,000 hectares of grazing land to protect shared resources across village boundaries and solve conflicts between farmers and pastoralists. Plans are underway to scale up this methodology through inclusion into national policy documents.

title_oics: CCAFS informed tools and approaches mainstreamed in Indian national program for targeting and scaling climate smart multi-commodity smallholder farming systems
title_project: Developing, adapting and targeting portfolios of CSA practices for sustainable intensification of smallholder and vulnerable farming systems in South Asia
scope_comments: The case studies from this outcome will help other NARS in South Asia (Nepal, Bangladesh, Pakistan) for targeting multi-commodity climate smart agriculture practices in smallholder farming systems

title_oics: Cards that farmers CAN read: on the way to improving the effectiveness of the Government of India’s Soil Health Card Scheme
title_project: 1.2.3 Decision Support Systems for R&D
scope_comments: The cards were adopted in the state of Bihar, with plans to adopt nationally.
outcome_impact_statement: India's Soil Health Card Scheme aims to provide every farmer with a card containing recommendations to improve management practices based on local soil measures. PIM found that farmers were not able to understand these cards, and designed a clearer and more user-friendly version. After testing and distribution of the redesigned cards in the state of Bihar, the Ministry of Agriculture plans to expand their use to the national level.

title_oics: PIM tools used in a project to foster gender-inclusive business models in small rural enterprises in Honduras
title_project: 3.3.1 Value Chain Hubs
outcome_impact_statement: The PIM-funded gender-sensitive LINK Methodology developed by CIAT is the cornerstone of the Rural Opportunities Project, funded by Global Affairs Canada and implemented by Swisscontact, CIAT, McGill University, and local partners in Honduras. In 2018 Swisscontact rural business advisors were trained in the use of this toolkit, designed to build inclusive commercial relationships linking rural producers with modern markets. It is hoped that this project will allow 450 small rural businesses and 2000 farmers to benefit from gender-inclusive business models.

title_oics: Adoption study: ex post sales survey
title_project: MasAgro Maiz
scope_comments: Project focused mainly on rainfed areas of Mexico.

title_oics: CGIAR Climate change West Africa Program informs the adoption of a public-private partnership business model for climate information services in Ghana
title_project: [Regional Program Leader] WA: Regional/National synthesis, engagement and support
outcome_impact_statement: Based on previous success stories from collaboration with CGIAR Program on climate change, agriculture & Food Security, Esoko, a private Information & Communication Technology (ICT) company, has taken up a Public-Private Partnership (PPP) business model proposed by CCAFS to allow sustainable and equitable dissemination of Climate Information Services. The PPP pilot which commenced in April 2018 now has 274,321 beneficiaries who have agreed to pay US$0.20 a month to receive timely market alerts and climate information on their mobile phones.

title_oics: Policies for improved food security and adaptation to climate change in the Philippines
title_project: 1.1.2 Improved Quantitative Strategic Foresight Modeling Tools and Applications
outcome_impact_statement: With support from CCAFS and PIM, an IFPRI team collaborated with the National Economic and Development Authority to inform government policies, plans, and investments for food security and adaptation to climate change in the Philippines. The team’s inputs were incorporated to the Philippines Development Plan 2017-2022 and the Rice Tariffication Law passed by the House and Senate in 2018.

title_oics: 86 organizations across Eastern Africa have adopted the volunteer farmer trainer approach, working with 17,600 volunteer farmer trainers to serve 352,000 farmers
title_project: 1.2.2 Agricultural Extension and Advisory Services
outcome_impact_statement: Since 2012, PIM has supported efforts by ICRAF and partners to implement the volunteer farmer trainer approach, learn more about the effectiveness, motivations, and sustainability of volunteer farmer trainers, disseminate findings, and monitor the uptake of this promising form of agricultural advice delivery in Eastern Africa. As of 2018, 86 organizations across Eastern Africa have adopted the volunteer farmer trainer approach. These organizations work with 17,600 volunteer farmer trainers and serve 352,000 farmers.

title_oics: Improving the design of the Government of Mali's social protection program for achieving better child nutrition
title_project: 4.1.2 Improving Design and Delivery of Social protection for Nutrition and Other Outcomes
outcome_impact_statement: In collaboration with the Government of Mali and and the Institut de Recherche pour le Developpement, a team of IFPRI/PIM researchers conducted an impact evaluation of Mali's cash transfer program "Projet Filets Sociaux (Jigisemejiri)". The recommendations of the evaluation have been used by the Government of Mali to improve the impacts of the program on child nutrition starting in 2019.

title_oics: The $74 million Nobo Jatra (New Beginning) USAID-funded project includes PIM findings to improve child nutrition in poor coastal areas of Bangladesh
title_project: 4.1.2 Improving Design and Delivery of Social protection for Nutrition and Other Outcomes
outcome_impact_statement: The results of the Transfer Modality Research Initiative informed the design of the conditional cash transfer of the Nobo Jatra (New Beginning) project, a 2016-2020 $74 million project funded by USAID and implemented by World Vision International in Southern Bangladesh.

title_oics: Improved targeting for the largest safety net program for ultra-poor women in rural Bangladesh, reaching 750,000 women and their 3.5 million family members
title_project: 4.1.2 Improving Design and Delivery of Social protection for Nutrition and Other Outcomes
outcome_impact_statement: PIM’s assessment of the largest safety net for ultra-poor women in rural Bangladesh, the Vulnerable Group Development (VGD) program, identified key deficiencies in the program's targeting criteria and recommended new criteria grounded more firmly on available poverty data. These criteria were adopted by the VGD program and by the new World Bank-supported Income Support Program for the Poorest.

title_oics: Strengthening the targeting performance of a child nutrition-oriented safety net in Bangladesh: the Improved Maternity and Lactating Mother Allowance
title_project: 4.1.2 Improving Design and Delivery of Social protection for Nutrition and Other Outcomes
outcome_impact_statement: Upon request of the Ministry of Women and Children Affairs of Bangladesh, IFPRI/PIM proposed eligibility criteria to strengthen the targeting performance of the Improved Maternity and Lactating Mother Allowance program in Bangladesh. The government accepted IFPRI's recommendations, which are anticipated to benefit approximately 700,000 poor rural and 250,000 poor urban women in 2018-2019.

title_oics: PIM findings used to develop the United States Government's strategy in Ethiopia
title_project: 2.4.1 Support to Ethiopia Policies
outcome_impact_statement: USAID used PIM research on growth and transformation, value chains and youth employment to frame challenges and opportunities in the Global Food Security Strategy Ethiopia Country Plan for 2018-2023, which serves as an overarching framework for integrated food security and nutrition programming.

title_oics: The United States Government uses PIM research on poverty, nutrition, demographics, and safety nets to design the Global Food Security Strategy Bangladesh Country Plan
title_project: 2.4.5 Support to Bangladesh Policies
outcome_impact_statement: USAID extensively consulted findings on poverty, nutrition, demographics, and safety nets from the IFPRI/PIM Bangladesh Policy Research and Strategy Support Program in the formulation of the United States Government Global Food Security Strategy Bangladesh Country Plan. Both the choice of the target location within the country and some thematic components of the Plan were informed by PIM research.

title_oics: PIM tools help USAID target countries for investments in food security
title_project: 2.1.4 Rural-Urban Linkages and Agri-Food System Employment
outcome_impact_statement: The USAID Global Food Security Strategy (GFSS) graduation framework is used to monitor countries' progress towards an end state where they can transition out of GFSS target country status. IFPRI's contributions to this framework, and thus to the selection of target countries for USAID's investments in food security, include: 1) assistance in selecting the indicators used to monitor country progress, 2) a tool aggregating indicator data into three composite dimensions, and 3) a scorecard approach to visually represent country progress.

title_oics: PIM's modeling expertise used to support the design of the agricultural investment strategies of Malawi and Rwanda
title_project: 2.1.4 Rural-Urban Linkages and Agri-Food System Employment
outcome_impact_statement: PIM research using computable general equilibrium modeling has informed the development of the National Agricultural Investment Plans of Malawi and Rwanda. These strategic documents provide a country-wide framework to coordinate and prioritize investments by government agencies, development partners and other actors in the agricultural sector.

title_oics: Informing the Government of Flanders' investment in agricultural advisory services to Malawian farmers
title_project: 2.2.2 Identifying Effective and Responsive Rural Service Delivery Systems
outcome_impact_statement: The Government of Flanders used PIM research on advisory services to farmers in Malawi for putting together their country strategy document for Malawi. Agricultural advisory services is one of four priority areas highlighted in this document and will benefit from an investment of 6 million euros from the Government of Flanders in 2019-2023.

title_oics: Improving returns to public investments in China’s agricultural sector
title_project: 2.2.1 Prioritization of Public Investments
outcome_impact_statement: Recommendations to improve the effectiveness of China’s public expenditures in the agricultural sector were prepared by IFPRI’s China Strategy Support Program team using the Statistics on Public Expenditures for Economic Development database, and shared with the Government of China and the Asian Development Bank. In line with these recommendations, changes have taken place in the country’s public expenditure policies, some of which are reflected in China’s new Rural Revitalization Strategy.

title_oics: PIM findings influence the Punjab Agricultural Policy and the Pakistan National Food Security Policy
title_project: 2.4.6 Asian Regional Policy Engagement
outcome_impact_statement: IFPRI/PIM contributed to two key policies adopted in 2018 in Pakistan: the Punjab Agricultural Policy, which lays out the province's framework for reform in agriculture, and the National Food Security Policy, which aims to eradicate hunger and malnutrition at the national level.

title_oics: Including women's empowerment as a key component of the United States’ global initiative to combat hunger – Role of the Women's Empowerment in Agriculture Index
title_project: 6.1.1 Women's Empowerment in Agriculture: Access to and Control over Resources
outcome_impact_statement: Findings using the Women's Empowerment in Agriculture Index helped the United States Government target key areas of women’s disempowerment in the design of Feed the Future country programs, and informed the United States Global Food Security Strategy Country Plans for Bangladesh, Ethiopia, Honduras, Kenya, and Nigeria.

title_oics: Enhanced capacity of the government of Malawi to evaluate the safety of genetically-engineered crops
title_project: 1.2.4 Comparative Science, Technology, and Innovation Systems in Developing-Country Agriculture
outcome_impact_statement: A team implementing IFPRI’s Program for Biosafety Systems (funded by USAID with support from PIM) contributed to developing the capacity of a network of regulatory experts to evaluate the safety of biotechnology products in Malawi and communicate their decisions clearly to stakeholders and the public.

title_oics: PIM research spurs collaboration and investments to reduce violence against women
title_project: 6.1.1 Women's Empowerment in Agriculture: Access to and Control over Resources
outcome_impact_statement: PIM research about the link between cash transfer programs and reduced intimate partner violence had led to the formation of the "Cash Transfer and Intimate Partner Violence Research Collaborative." Comprised of researchers from various academic and development organizations (IFPRI, United Nations, three universities), the collaborative is tasked with moving forward a research agenda and informing decision makers about findings related to the potential of cash transfer programs for reducing violence against women.

title_oics: Participation of National Agrarian University La Molina (Peru) in research on indigenous tenure security leads to changes in forestry curriculum
title_project: 5.2.1 Governing Shared Landscapes
outcome_impact_statement: PIM partnered with the Forestry Department of the National Agrarian University La Molina in Peru to study land and forest tenure security of indigenous communities using multi-method participatory research. The outcomes of this process include increased knowledge and research capacity of university staff on tenure, gender, and indigenous issues, and changes to the Forest Engineer curriculum to include more social science.

title_oics: Implementation of satellite-based rice monitoring system in Philippines and the states of Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu of India
title_project: IRRI Contribution to RICE Flagship Project 1
scope_comments: Adoption is best documented in the Philippines
outcome_impact_statement: Use of crop monitoring systems based on a combination of satellite remote sensing, geographic information systems, crop growth simulation modeling, and on-the-ground information to provide governments up-to-date information on 'the state of the rice crop' (acreage, yield and production forecast, storm damage) . The use of such systems to support crop insurance programs is being tested in the states of Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu, India.

title_oics: Revolving credit fund for farmers of dairy cooperative KPSBU to make investments for improved manure management
title_project: WUR Sustainable intensification of dairy production in Indonesia

title_oics: Expansion of the 'seeds without borders' agreement to Bhutan
title_project: IRRI Contribution to RICE Flagship Project 1
outcome_impact_statement: Bhutan can now import improved variety seeds without much hassle from six countries in the region. Bangladesh, Cambodia, India, Myanmar, Nepal, and Sri Lanka are the other members of the network agreement.

title_project: PIM Monitoring and Evaluation

title_oics: RHoMIS (a rapid, standardized, cost-effective agricultural performance tracking tool) adopted by 13 organisations to guide investments and generate information on 24,000 households in 31 countries
title_project: Activity 4.1.1  Evaluate and quantify global environmental change risks and opportunities and impacts and possible trade-offs by age and gender.
outcome_impact_statement: The Rural Household Multi Indicator Survey (RHoMIS) is a standardized household survey tool developed by the International Livestock Research Institute and partners.  It has been used by 13 research and development organizations (TreeAID, Global Diversity Foundation, SNV, ICRAF, IFAD, EU-JRC, Bioversity International, FAO, CIAT, IITA, WUR, CSIRO and McKnight Foundation) in 31 countries, reaching over 21,000 households.  The tool allows data from many projects to be pooled, building up a coherent, large dataset permitting cross-site analysis.

title_oics: A4NH research informs the design of a $13 million donor investment in improving food safety in six countries in Africa and one state in India
title_project: Better evidence on foodborne disease in target regions
outcome_impact_statement: The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and the UK Department for International Development used cumulative ILRI evidence on food safety burden and management in informal markets to shape their first joint investment in food safety. In response to the call, six grants totalling $13 million were awarded. Evidence-based interventions will be tested at a large-scale, potentially reducing food-borne disease risks for millions of consumers in Ethiopia, Burkina Faso, Kenya, Mozambique, Nigeria, Tanzania and one state in India.

title_oics: “Reach, Benefit, Empower" framework of indicators for monitoring programs and policies incorporated into trainings conducted by partners
title_project: Tools and methods to assess and deliver impact of nutrition-sensitive agricultural programs
scope_comments: two pilot studies planned in Malawi and Benin in 2019-2020
outcome_impact_statement: CGIAR researchers have developed a framework that identifies a need for projects and programs to distinguish between approaches that ‘reach’ women as participants, those that actually ‘benefit’ women and finally those that ‘empower’ them. This Reach, Benefit, Empower (RBE) framework has been published in a journal article and has been used by The Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit GmbH (GIZ) and The International Development Research Centre (IDRC) in presentations.

title_oics: Agricultural Transformation Agency's Improved seed marketing system in Ethiopia scaled up to 1.4 million farmers based on a PIM evaluation
title_project: 3.2.3 Linking Smallholders to Dynamic Markets
outcome_impact_statement: In 2013-14, PIM researchers teamed up with the Ethiopian Agricultural Transformation Agency to test a pilot Direct Seed Marketing Program which intended to increase the participation of the private sector in the multiplication and marketing of high quality seed. The study found that the program led to many positive outcomes, and the Agricultural Transformation Agency subsequently expanded it. In 2018, the program was used in 228 districts, involving 47 seed producers and benefiting 1.4 million farmers.

title_oics: Adoption of Alternate wetting and drying in Asia to save water and reduce methane emissions
title_project: IRRI contribution to RICE Flagship Project 3
outcome_impact_statement: Alternate wetting and drying is a water saving technology that enables irrigated rice cultivation with less water than the conventional practice of maintaining the field continuously flooded. This technology can reduce water input and GHG without yield penalty. AWD has been integrated in major national rice crop management guidelines in Vietnam, China and the Philippines and dissemination has started in all countries above. Several rice-producing countries mention AWD in their contributions to the Paris Agreement..

title_oics: Adoption of Rice Crop Manager
title_project: IRRI contribution to RICE Flagship Project 3
outcome_impact_statement: RCM is a decision-support tool designed for use by extension workers, crop advisors, agricultural service providers, and farmer leaders. It is accessible online on personal computers, tablets, or smartphones.  In Philippines, more than 1.7 M recommendations generated for farmers in 2014-2018.  In Odisha, India, around 100 thousand farmers have received recommendations in 2016-18.

title_oics: Uptake and use of gender research methodologies and tools from the project “GENNOVATE” by agriculture researchers worldwide
outcome_impact_statement: GENNOVATE is a global comparative research initiative that addresses the question of how gender norms and agency influence men, women, and youth to adopt innovation in agriculture and natural resource management. Findings from this work are being taken up by international agricultural researchers and impacting how they work and how they target their work to better reach men, women and youth.

title_oics: Uptake and use of gender research approaches and tools from the project “GENNOVATE” by agriculture researchers worldwide
outcome_impact_statement: GENNOVATE is a global comparative research initiative across 11 CGIAR Research Programs that addresses the question of how gender norms and agency influence men, women, and youth to adopt innovation in agriculture and natural resource management. Findings from this work are being taken up by international and national agricultural researchers and impacting how they how they target, plan and realize their research work to better reach men, women and youth.

title_oics: Adoption of improved rice management practices in Southeast Asia
title_project: IRRI contribution to RICE Flagship Project 3

title_oics: Drill-sown direct seeded rice in Nepal
title_project: IRRI contribution to RICE Flagship Project 3

title_oics: Adoption of Premium Quality Rice varieties BRRI Dhan 50 and BRRI Dhan 63 in Bangladesh
title_project: IRRI contribution to RICE Flagship project 5

title_oics: Adoption of flood-tolerant rice varieties in Bangladesh (sub1)
title_project: IRRI contribution to RICE Flagship project 5
outcome_impact_statement: In the flood-prone areas of Northern Bangladesh, adoption of flood-tolerant varieties decreased rice production damage by flood, thereby increasing profitability, ensuring food security and reducing poverty.

title_oics: Adoption of '1 Must Do - 5 Reductions' rice management practices in Vietnam
title_project: IRRI contribution to RICE Flagship Project 3
outcome_impact_statement: In Vietnam, 1 Must 5 Reductions (1M5R) is certified by a Presidential decree (532-QD-TT-CLT) as the national policy to promote best management practices in lowland rice cultivation. The use of 1M5R focused on reduction of seed and pesticide inputs. This management reduced the production costs by 23% reducing the production by 203 US$/ha per season, and generating 19% additional income, 175 US$/ha more. The adoption of this technology was 28% more beneficial compared to farmers who did not follow 1M5R.

title_oics: Faster farmer replacement of improved wheat varieties provides resilience and income; laid a foundation for Ethiopian wheat self-sufficiency
scope_comments: Agronomic practices and rusts-resistant varieties also relevant to other East African countries.
outcome_impact_statement: Building on past successes facilitating adoption of improved wheat seed with higher on farm yields, and support for disease monitoring and diagnostics, CGIAR (WHEAT, PIM) researchers identified necessary conditions to allow farmers to more rapidly replace traditional varieties with improved varieties. This contributes to improved resilience and incomes among Ethiopian wheat farmers, and laid a foundation for Ethiopia's goal of wheat self-sufficiency.

title_oics: Adoption of smart-valley approach in Benin and Togo
title_project: AfricaRice contribution to RICE Flagship Project 3
outcome_impact_statement: In order to improve water control and soil management and increase the productivity of rice, a new technology (smart-valley approach) was introduced in Benin and Togo since 2010. This study assessed its adoption, the diffusion and impact of smart-valley approach among 590 farming households. Adoption increased from 110 ha in 2012 to 474 ha in 2014. Adoption increased yield by 0.9 tons ha⁻¹, and net income by USD 267 per hectare.

title_oics: Impact of Submergence-Tolerant Rice Varieties on Smallholders' Income and Expenditure: Farm-Level Evidence from Bangladesh
title_project: IRRI Contribution to RICE Flagship Project 1

title_oics: Production and dissemination of quality seed of new rice varieties in South Asia
title_project: IRRI Contribution to RICE Flagship Project 1

title_oics: Assessment of functioning of multi-stakeholder platforms in Africa
title_project: AfricaRice Contribution to RICE Flagship Project 1

title_oics: Empowerment of rural women in Cote d'Ivoire and Madagascar
title_project: AfricaRice Contribution to RICE Flagship Project 1

title_oics: Seed and variety dissemination roadmaps in Africa
title_project: AfricaRice Contribution to RICE Flagship Project 1

title_oics: Female participation in adoption and sowing of improved rice varieties.
title_project: CIAT Contribution to RICE Flagship Project 1

title_oics: Adoption of healthy rice seedling practices in CSISA-project areas Bangladesh
title_project: IRRI contribution to RICE Flagship Project 3

title_oics: Mechanization (use of reaper-harvester) in Nepal
title_project: IRRI contribution to RICE Flagship Project 3

title_oics: Use of RiceAdvice decision support tool in Sub-Sahara Africa
title_project: IRRI contribution to RICE Flagship Project 3

title_oics: Quantifying the impacts of the use of potentially new herbicides in Bangladesh
title_project: IRRI contribution to RICE Flagship Project 3

title_oics: Factors driving large-scale adoption of sustainable intensification practices in the Indo-Gangetic Plain (Cereal Systems Initiative for South Asia - CSISA)
outcome_impact_statement: Research by the CIMMYT-led Cereal Systems Initiative for South Asia (CSISA) under WHEAT and RICE identified proven factors and business models that positively impacted farmers’ adoption of sustainable intensification and climate smart farming practices. These findings and pilots built on them, when scaled up, help government agencies prioritize the portfolio of climate smart agricultural practices that can maximize crop productivity, profitability and input use efficiency, while improving farmer capacity and reducing the environmental footprint.

title_oics: Improved cattle feeding practices in nine Kenyan counties, resulting in increased milk productivity for close to 80,000 farmers, with likely improved income and livelihoods
title_project:
Activity 5.4.4 Livestock Market System Performance
It corresponds to the product line on 'Menu of organizational and business models for improved livestock value chain performance'
scope_comments: The dairy value chain work focused in nine counties: Migori, Kisumu, Vihiga, Siaya, Busia, Homa Bay, Taita Taveta, Kitui and Makueni.  It is applicable to other non-traditional dairy farming areas.
outcome_impact_statement: From 2015-2018, the Accelerated Value Chain Development project aimed to support the dairy sector in non-traditional dairy regions of Kenya. A key constraint to milk production is feed. Using the Feed Assessment Tool (FEAST) tool, Brachiara grass was identified as the most suitable feed option. The second step included its dissemination and improving its use including commercialisation. These activities resulted in an increase in milk production per cow, with likely positive effects on income and other aspects of farmers' livelihoods.

title_oics: Impact evaluation of nutrition sensitive intervention scaled up through preschools
title_project: Evidence of impacts, impact pathways, synergies and cost-effectiveness of nutrition-sensitive agricultural programs
outcome_impact_statement: The World Bank and the Government of Malawi agreed in June 2018 to scale-up a nutrition-sensitive intervention based on results from an IFPRI-led impact evaluation which showed that preschools can be an effective platform for delivering a nutrition-sensitive agricultural intervention. This will start in 2019.

title_oics: Inter-ministerial Ordinance 284/2018 (Brazil) and new “sociobiodiversity label” incentivize farmers to continue growing and selling local species via institutional procurement and alternative market channels
title_project: Policy process analysis and policy engagement
outcome_impact_statement: Innovative multi-sectoral policy platforms bring together the environment, agriculture and health sectors. In Brazil, partners mainstreamed nutritious food biodiversity into policies that support smallholder farmer livelihoods, local agriculture, and improved nutrition, with a focus on institutional procurement.

title_oics: Evaluation of a water management training program in Tajikistan leads to redesign to target women farmers and informs Feed the Future Learning Agenda(WLE-IWMI)
title_project: Water and irrigation in Central Asia (Bilateral activity cluster)
outcome_impact_statement: United States Agency for International Development(USAID) re-oriented an irrigation investment in Tajikistan to include women, based on results of a study by the CGIAR Research Program on Water, Land and Ecosystems (WLE) and partners. The study evaluated the effectiveness of a water management training program. While the training is indeed effective in improving crop and water management, women were excluded from training despite their growing role in water management, as men migrate away and out of farming.

title_oics: Annual Agriculture Nutrition and Health Academy Week strengthens interdisciplinary research capacity among individuals from low- and middle-income research institutions
title_project: Improving awareness and understanding of interactions between agriculture and human health and building inter-sectoral collaboration to address complex challenges
outcome_impact_statement: The Agriculture, Nutrition and Health Academy Week has helped convene a global community of researchers and research users working on agriculture, nutrition, and health challenges. Since 2016, A4NH have co-organized this annual event with the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine (LSHTM).  These events have enhanced individual capacity of early career researchers from low- and middle-income countries in terms of research involvement and skills and filled a gap in networking and mutual learning opportunities around agriculture, nutrition, and health

title_oics: Mobile phone-based surveillance system implemented in Turkana County, Kenya has improved the delivery of animal health and food safety interventions in the county
title_project: Technological and institutional innovations for assessing, communicating and mitigating food safety risks designed and tested, with capacity building (Product Lines)
scope_comments: Turkana County
outcome_impact_statement: In partnership with the Department of Veterinary Services (DVS), Turkana County, Kenya, we developed and deployed a mobile phone-based surveillance system for livestock diseases and syndromes. It has been used to collect and analyse livestock disease data and abattoir records. The DVS has budgeted for its costs of implementation and appointed technical personnel to run the system. Towards the end of 2018, the DVS used the maps generated by the system to inform the distribution of veterinary vaccines and drugs.

title_oics: Use of global rice sustainability standards
title_project: IRRI contribution to RICE Flagship Project 3
outcome_impact_statement:
The Sustainable Rice Platform (SRP) Standard for Sustainable Rice Cultivation is the world’s first voluntary sustainability standard for rice.
The Standard defines a set of key requirements with different levels of performance allowing for a stepwise improvement and compliance process. Many of the over 80 SRP members are testing, adopting, and implementing the SRP standards in different parts of the world. Full details are available on the SRP website at: http://www.sustainablerice.org/Resources/#local-action.

title_oics: East African Community (EAC) uses aflatoxin technical papers to prepare aflatoxin policy briefs that are endorsed by the Council of Ministers of the EAC.
title_project: Technological and institutional innovations for assessing and mitigating food safety risks related to aflatoxins designed and tested, including capacity building
outcome_impact_statement: For the East African Community (EAC), IITA prepared 11 Technical Papers (TPs) on key sectoral issues impacted by aflatoxins. All available evidence of each sector was comprehensively reviewed, and action plans recommended to manage the impacts. Establishment and sharing of this knowledge base laid the foundation for policies to address the aflatoxin-related food safety issues. The TPs guided the EAC secretariat to prepare nine policy briefs that were endorsed by the EAC Council of Ministers and publicly released.

title_oics: Aflasafe products to reduce aflatoxin crop contamination are now registered in eight countries—three new countries in 2018
title_project: Technological and institutional innovations for assessing and mitigating food safety risks related to aflatoxins designed and tested, including capacity building
scope_comments: Aflasafe products will be registered in the next couple of years in additional nations.
outcome_impact_statement: In 2018, Aflasafe products were registered in Ghana, Zambia, and Tanzania — two products per country. Each Aflasafe product contains four native atoxigenic Aspergillus flavus strains. Registration was granted based on results of hundreds of farmer field efficacy trials, in multiple agroecological zones, during multiple years. Aflatoxin reductions in treated crops ranged from 80% to 100% less compared to untreated adjoining crops. Scaling activities in each country have begun and include development of commercialization strategies, manufacturing infrastructure, and technology transfer.

title_oics: Assessment of the use of Participatory Integrated Climate Services for Agriculture (PICSA) approach by farmers to manage climate risk in Mali and Senegal
title_project: [Flagship Leader] FP4: Engagement, synthesis and support

title_oics: Strengthening climate services for the food security sector
title_project: [Flagship Leader] FP4: Engagement, synthesis and support

title_oics: Implementación de Servicios Integrados Participativos de Clima para la Agricultura (PICSA) en el TESAC - Cauca Colombia
title_project: [Flagship Leader] FP4: Engagement, synthesis and support

title_oics: CGIAR Review 2018: External EC review of CCAFS
title_project: [Program Management Unit] CCAFS Coordinating Unit CIAT

title_oics: The Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR) prioritized nutrition in breeding by establishing minimum levels of iron and zinc to breed in pearl millet
title_project: Biofortified varieties
outcome_impact_statement: In 2018, the Indian Council on Agriculture Research established minimum levels of iron and zinc for their pearl millet breeding program, levels informed by joint research with CGIAR. This change means that all future releases of pearl millet varieties in India will be more nutritious and iron and zinc intake will improve among pearl millet consuming populations.

title_oics: The 2017 Inspire Challenge:  Innovation Strategies for Digital Agriculture
title_project: Inspire Challenge Module 3
scope_comments: This study of the Inspire Challenge in light of innovation strategy looked in part at countries and geographic areas targeted by digital innovators, with an eye toward identifying features of enabling environments for these data-driven solutions to take root.

title_oics: Harnessing Ethiopian floodwaters helps dryland pastoralists – and the approach is being scaled up (WLE-ICRISAT)
title_project: Integrated Watershed Management for enhanced productivity with sustained environmental services
scope_comments: Chifra, Ewa, and Yallo districts of Afar
outcome_impact_statement: The government of Afar state, Ethiopia, has adopted a landscape-level water spreading approach demonstrated by the CGIAR Research Program on Water, Land and Ecosystems (WLE) and partners in dry lowland areas. The approach reduces destruction from flooding and spreads water across pastures and cultivated fields, increasing their productivity. This approach has been integrated into a proposed project supported by the World Bank and International Fund for Agricultural Development.

title_oics: A revolution in solar-powered Irrigation: Solar Power as Remunerative Crop (SPaRC) model is being scaled out nationwide in India  (WLE-IWMI)
title_project: ALWM investment models for livelihood benefits (Bilateral activity cluster) (IlSSI)
outcome_impact_statement: A cooperative business model developed by the CGIAR Research Program on Water, Land and Ecosystems (WLE) and partners is now formally confirmed as one of four components of a total USD 16.4 billion Indian Government farm energy program (KUSUM). Gujarat state has begun scaling out the concept; six other states have begun piloting it under KUSUM. In the model, cooperatives manage a small solar-powered grid for irrigation pumps that sell surplus power to the electric utility.

title_oics: Water planning system “Agua de Honduras” used to improve Honduran investment decisions (WLE-CIAT)
title_project: Restoration of deforested areas in the Colombian and Peruvian Amazon ? socioeconomic and biophysical indicators, determinants and limitations of/for success.
outcome_impact_statement: The Government of Honduras piloted and adopted a major new data platform, “Agua de Honduras” that provides data on hydrology, vegetative cover, soil properties, along with future climate scenarios. Implemented by the Centro Internacional de Agricultura Tropical (CIAT) and contributing to the CGIAR Research Program on Water, Land and Ecosystems (WLE), the platform has been aiding water management decisions, including being used 150 times to identify rainwater harvesting sites and influencing at least one local land investment decision.

title_oics: Soil-plant spectral technology guiding soil fertility investments in Africa (WLE-ICRAF)
title_project: Land Restoration Planning and Performance Management
outcome_impact_statement: Seventeen African countries are now using soil–plant spectral technology developed by CGIAR Research Program on Water, Land and Ecosystems (WLE) and partners to restore soils and boost agricultural production. The Africa Soil Information Service (AfSIS) is now being deployed for targeting soil fertility restoration strategies. Ethiopia, Ghana, Nigeria, and Tanzania have established state-of-the-art soil information systems based on the technology. NGOs and the private sector are delivering soil testing services to smallholder farmers and monitor intervention impacts on soil health.

title_oics: Environmental water flows go global to support implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) (WLE-IWMI)
title_project: Support to the roll-out of SDG monitoring and reporting by countries enhancing food security and sustainabile use of water resource use
outcome_impact_statement: CGIAR Research Program on Water, Land and Ecosystems (WLE) and partners have been leading efforts to include environmental flows (e-flows) in the SDG Indicator 6.4.2 on water stress.  WLE led the preparation of a guideline to support countries’ reporting on e-flows. This methodology is being distributed by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) to all countries to monitor progress on SDG 6.4 on alleviating water scarcity.

title_oics: Making the leap from drought monitoring to managing agricultural drought risks in India (WLE-IWMI)
title_project: New approaches to monitoring and managing floods and droughts in India and Sri Lanka
outcome_impact_statement: The South Asia Drought Monitoring System (SADMS), created by the CGIAR Research Program on Water, Land and Ecosystems (WLE) and partners, provided real-time drought severity data at micro-level to three Indian districts. The crop yields and incomes in these areas were significantly higher than in the control areas. As a result, the Indian government and World Bank plan to scale out the model.

title_oics: Fast-tracking maize varietal replacement in Ethiopia.
outcome_impact_statement: The replacement of older, climate-vulnerable maize varieties with improved climate-resilient hybrids into stress-prone maize farming systems has contributed to improved productivity and food subsistence in Ethiopia. MAIZE has been instrumental in fast-tracking maize varietal replacement in Ethiopia through successful engagement with public- and private-sector institutions. MAIZE’s successful development and commercialization of improved maize varieties, in particular variety BH661, through projects like NuME, DTMA and WEMA, offers a valuable model for breeders, seed companies, extension agents, regulatory and policy makers.

title_oics: Improved drought tolerant maize varieties led to improved yields and livelihoods in Nigeria
outcome_impact_statement: The Drought_Tolerant_Maize_for Africa (DTMA) project, followed by the Stress_Tolerant_Maize_for_Africa (STMA) project, have delivered valuable results to smallholder_farmers through improved drought and stress tolerant_maize varieties. Over 200 distinct drought_tolerant (DT) maize_hybrids and open_pollinated varieties (OPV) were released throughout the projects_lifetime, of which 54,000 tons of certified DT_maize_seed was produced, benefiting an estimated 5.4 million households_or 43 million people. These impacts continue into the present day_a 2018 ex-post assessment found that adoption of improved_varieties in Nigeria allowed_farmers to increased maize_grain_yield by 574_kg/ha_(32%).

title_oics: Cocoa of Excellence Programme provided visibility and improved processing techniques and final quality
title_project: 4. Biodiversity, safeguarding and conservation
scope_comments: The Cocoa of Excellence Programme involves more than 50 cocoa producing countries. Country per Regional Area. Africa and Indian Ocean: Cameroon, Congo DRC, Congo Rep, Cote d?Ivoire, Equatorial Guinea, Ghana, Madagascar, Nigeria, Sao Tome and Principe, Sierra Leone, Tanzania, Togo. Asia, Pacific and Australia: Australia, Fiji, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Vanuatu, Vietnam. Central America and Caribbean: Costa Rica, Dominica, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Grenada, Guatemala, Haiti, Hawaii, Honduras, Martinique, Mexico, Nicaragua, Puerto Rico, Trinidad and Tobago, El Salvador. South America: Bolivia, Brazil, Colombia, French, Guyana, Peru, Venezuela.
outcome_impact_statement: The Cocoa of Excellence Programme has been recognized by participants in facilitating connection between cocoa producers and other relevant stakeholders, providing not only an international platform and major visibility, but also tools to improve fermenting and roasting techniques. The Programme is considered a unique way to promote cocoa diversity and expression of terroir, putting at the centre the cocoa producer. The promotion of high quality cocoa linked to the work done at farm level has potential to improve farmers livelihood in the long term.

title_oics: Results Framework Review
title_project: WLE Program Management Unit

title_oics: Indicator Reference Sheets
title_project: WLE Program Management Unit

title_oics: CRP evaluation, outcome story and impact assessment planning
title_project: WLE Program Management Unit

title_oics: Review and implementation of results-based management system
title_project: WLE Program Management Unit

title_oics: CRP Thematic Evaluation: TBA after consultation
title_project: WLE Program Management Unit

title_oics: New World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) typology of public-private partnerships in support of national veterinary services
title_project: Activity 2.4.1 Animal Health Service provision
outcome_impact_statement: The World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) is a key institution regulating international trade of livestock and livestock products. In its endeavour to strengthen veterinary service delivery, the OIE, in consultation with experts, conducted a survey on experiences with public-private partnerships (PPPs) in 181 countries to identify case stories in the field of Veterinary Services.  The CRP Livestock contributed case stories to this exercise based on tested PPP models in Kenya, Tanzania and Ethiopia.

title_oics: Livestock Master Plan in Rwanda influences the government in shaping investments in the livestock sector as well as the Plan for Agriculture Transformation
title_project: Activity 5.1.3 Policy Identification and generation
outcome_impact_statement: ILRI and partners have coordinated the development of Livestock Master Plans in a couple of countries, including Ethiopia as reported in 2017. In Rwanda, the work was coordinated by FAO with support from ILRI. In 2018, the document was finalised. Even through it was not officially gazetted, it has influenced the government view of the livestock sector. In particular, the evidence was reflected in the new Plan for Agriculture Transformation (PSTA4, 2018-2024).

title_oics: Incorporation of developing country perspective in World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) guidelines on prioritization of animal diseases for which vaccines could reduce antimicrobial use
title_project: Activity 2.2.2 Establish protocols for survey of antimicrobial use and for monitoring AMR
outcome_impact_statement: The World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) is a key institution for global veterinary policy and its outputs help regulate international trade of livestock and livestock products. The guideline was developed in support of the Global Action Plan on antimicrobial resistance (AMR) and helps to identify where private and public sector vaccine research and development activities should focus. ILRI's participation drew attention to developing country issues such as key diseases, challenges for vaccine uptake and the importance of delivery systems.

title_oics: Creation of an enabling environment for improved land tenure reform in Uganda
title_project: 21. Quality of FTA research for development
outcome_impact_statement: Increased knowledge and understanding of the importance of tenure reform among NGOs, forest adjacent communities and technocrats. National stakeholders credited the project with being the main influence on how the gendered implications of forest tenure reform were understood nationally.

title_oics: Outcome Evaluation Of Research For Development Work Conducted In Ghana And Sri Lanka Under The Resource, Recovery And Reuse (RRR) Subprogram of WLE
title_project: WLE Program Management Unit

title_oics: About 3M households are cultivating CIP-related potato varieties in China and six countries in Southeast and South-Asia
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: This study documents the release and adoption of improved potato varieties (IVs) in seven major potato producing countries in Southeast, South, and East Asia. Data on varietal release from 1952 to 2015 was considered. Of over a total of 491 IVs released, 210 (43%) are adopted and cultivated; 63 of those are CIP-related IVs. In 2015, potato cultivated area was 7.6M ha and 97% was planted to IVs. 19% (1.4M ha) of this area was planted to CIP-related IVs.

title_oics: In Southeast and South-Asia, CIP-related varieties cover 5% (164,000 ha) of the of the total area planted to sweetpotato (3.6M ha).
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: This study documents the release and adoption of improved sweetpotato varieties in eight major producing countries in Southeast, South, and East Asia. Data on varietal release shows that over a total of 434 varieties released, 195 (45%) are adopted and cultivated; 45 of the 434 are CIP-related varieties. In 2015, sweetpotato cultivated area was 3.6M ha and 88% was planted to improved varieties. 5% (164,000 ha) of this area was planted to CIP-related varieties.

title_oics: Adoption estimates of improved cassava varieties in nine countries in South and Southeast Asia indicate that 2.7 million hectares are grown using CIAT-related varieties
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Adoption estimates of improved cassava varieties indicate that out of 4.1 million of hectares of cassava production targeted in nine countries, 2.7 million (68%) are grown using CIAT-related varieties.  however, the level of adoption of varieties varies from country to country implying different level of success of different cassava genetic improvement programs in the region.

title_oics: Kenya Plant Health Inspectorate Service (KEPHIS), research, development partners and private sector have joined forces to reduce the incidence of potato cyst nematodes in Kenya
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Evidence-based surveillance and management strategy to reduce the incidence and limit the spread of potato cyst nematodes is being developed and implemented in Kenya. Stakeholders from public, private and research for development sectors are collaborating to strengthen national capacity to cope with this new invasive threat.

title_oics: Successful scaling up of biofortified crops to fight against hidden hunger in Nigeria, Tanzania and surrounding region through strong advocacy efforts and supportive policy environment
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: A multi-stakeholder partnership led by CIP contributed in making biofortification a priority in 11 national and regional policy and strategy documents and mobilized about $6.5M in Nigeria and Tanzania. It has influenced seven programmes and built capacities of 40+ agencies. Four learning toolkits developed, which trained 11,433 (5,976 female) change agents, who can lead gender-sensitive projects with a nutritious food-basket approach. 7 biofortified crop varieties have been fast tracked. Almost 1M households are growing biofortified crops in Tanzania and Nigeria

title_oics: Proper infant and young child feeding practices provided by caregivers in Kenya were enhanced through promotion and continued nutrition education
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Nutrition education and psychosocial factors have a positive influence on the degree to which infant and young child feeding (IYCF) practices are used. After the intervention, about 21% of the women provided children with diverse diets, and 20% of the women had incorporated OFSP in the diets of young children. These findings imply that there is a need for continued nutrition education of caregivers on proper IYCF.

title_oics: Feeding children's futures in rural Cambodia
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Since 2016, the Feed the Future Cambodia Rice Field Fisheries II project has supported 12,300 households in 134 community fish refuges (CFRs) to improve their food and nutrition security and to reduce poverty by applying good practices to conserve and increase fish stocks and improve nutrition. In 2018, the amount of fish caught has increased by 30%, 104,478 people have consumed more fish at home and the proportion of children under five eating small fish has increased by 50%.

title_oics: Myanmar Government approved the Agricultural Development Strategy and the 'Naypyitaw Agreement' that enables the spread of nutritious and profitable rice-fish farming practices.
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Research demonstrates rice-fish systems enable families to grow enough fish to consume weekly, thereby having a positive effect on household nutrition, with particularly potential to increase nutrition status of children. Informed by FISH research and convening, the Myanmar Government approved the Agricultural Development Strategy and the 'Naypyitaw Agreement' that legitimizes and enables the spread of rice-fish practices.

title_oics: Employment generation in the Egyptian aquaculture value chain
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Investing in aquaculture innovations has the potential to greatly increase profitability for fish farms in Egypt. Increasing profitability can be mainly achieved by cost savings through more efficient feed management rather than increased production. As an additional benefit, we have identified the contribution of aquaculture sector to job creation in Egypt. Potentially 19.1 Full Time Equivalent (FTE) jobs can be generated per 100t of produced fish along the entire aquaculture value chain in Egypt.

title_oics: Bringing the Arbuscular Mycorrhiza (AM) Biofertilizer in Uganda
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: In Uganda, the biofertilizers available on the market are often imported and economically out of reach for many smallholder farmers. In a joint effort, national and international partners have carried out the first competence transferral training in Uganda to produce arbuscular mycorrhiza (AM) biofertilizer for inoculation. Protagonists of this pivotal activity were students and staff of the Makerere University and Uganda NARO, now able to foster the uptake of AM nationally for increased food security.

title_oics: Scaling-up Participatory Research of High Yielding Pigeonpea Hybrids: Enabling the Potential for Increased Productivity of Smallholders Farmers Sharing Best Practices and Improved Seeds
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: To harness the potential benefits of hybrid pigeonpea in the targeted states, ICRISAT-led consortium provided technical support to formulate, monitor and demonstrate science-led best management practices to cover 7500 ha area in five states directly and 100000 ha indirectly. The consortium of DoAs, SAUs, KVKs, NGOs, CBOs and progressive farmers worked towards promoting best bet practices viz, balanced nutrient management, BBF/R&F, dibbling, nipping, integrated approach in pest/weed management/irrigation management etc.

title_oics: Efficient Legume Seed Systems for Better Smallholder Farmers’ Livelihoods in the Semi-Arid Tropics
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: The project supported production of 36123.06 tons of certified/ Quality Declared Seed (QDS) that could plant about 619,017 ha of land at an average seed rate of about 60kg/ha across crops. With this area under legumes and with average productivity of 1.096t/ha, an estimated 677,862 tons of grain valued at USD 353.71 million will be produced. This is estimated that the project has a potential of reaching 1,130,731 households at an average landholding of about 0.5 ha/household.

title_oics: 698 tons of Quality Declared Seed (QDS) produced by a network of seed producers, potentially reaching over 230,000 households in Ethiopia, Tanzania, Uganda, Burkina Faso, Mali and Nigeria
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: The project supported production of 698 tons of certified/ Quality Declared Seed (QDS) that would plant about 94,277 ha of land at an average seed rate of 0.006tons/ha, reaching an estimated 232,864 households in Ethiopia, Tanzania, Uganda, Burkina Faso, Mali and Nigeria at an average landholding of 0.4 ha/household. With an average productivity of 1.179t/ha across the three crops, the certified seed will be used to produce an estimated 94,095 tons of grain valued at USD 28 million.

title_oics: Biofortified Cultivars of Grain Legumes and Dryland Cereals Development, Mainstreamed and Adopted in India Improving Food Security and Wellness
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: The year 2018 has witnessed release of 17 biofortified varieties of GLDC crops in South Asia and Sub-Saharan Africa,  two regions with more malnourished people in the world. This was possible due to mainstreaming biofortification in breeding programs at ICARDA, ICRISAT, and IITA. Adoption of biofortified cultivars have made significant contribution on production and consumption of nutritious foods.

title_oics: Access to improved chickpea as pathway for rural development
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: The team found that farmers' comparative advantage does not play a significant role in their adoption decisions and hypothesize that this is due to the overall high economic returns to adoption, despite the limited yield impacts of the technology. The results suggest economic measures of returns may be more relevant than increases in yields in explaining technology adoption decisions and the process that led to the impacts.

title_oics: Impact of ICRISAT Pearl Millet Hybrid Parents Research Consortium (PMHPRC) on the Livelihoods of Farmers in India
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: ICRISAT commissioned third-party evaluation in 2015 to assess on-farm impact of pearl millet hybrids developed by Pearl Millet Hybrid Parents Research Consortium (PMHPRC) members during 2000-2010 (based directly or indirectly on ICRISAT breeding lines) in India. The study covered 563 pearl millet growers spanning 57 villages, 25 mandals from three states (Rajasthan, Gujarat and Uttar Pradesh) in India. The study revealed that PMHPRC hybrids covered about 60% of pearl millet hybrid area in the 3 states during 2013-14.

title_oics: Bhoosamrudhi: Improving Rural Livelihoods through Innovative Scaling-up of Science-led Participatory Research for Development
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: The program, started in 2013, covered 80,000 ha and tested various innovative technologies at each pilot site in Karnataka state, India. Integrated Nutrient Management (INM), Integrated Pest Management (IPM), water management, mechanization, crop intensification, crop diversification and fodder development were promoted. A consortium of national and international research institutes was formed to scale up various Natural Resources Management (NRM) technologies. Best management practices along with improved cultivars increased crop yield by 15-40%.

title_oics: Policy favours biofortified pearl millet in India to combat Fe and Zn deficiencies
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: The All India Coordinated Research Project on Pearl Millet (AICRP-PM) of Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR) has established minimum levels of iron and zinc to be bred into national varieties of pearl millet. The policy favours biofortified pearl millet in India and thus contributes to alleviate burden of malnutrition. Biofortification is a simple, sustainable and nutrition sensitive agricultural innovation and favorable policies for biofortified crops is a game changer to drive nutrition security.

title_oics: Providing a framework for the Myanmar government’s policies, programs and investments on climate-smart agriculture
title_project: [Regional Program Leader] SEA: Regional and National synthesis, engagement and support
outcome_impact_statement: In 2015, the Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock, and Irrigation (MOALI), together with CCAFS, developed the Myanmar Climate-Smart Agricultural Strategy (MCSAS) to guide the implementation of climate actions in Myanmar. To date, MCSAS has been referenced in at least 19 government and NGO programs, 4 policy documents, and 19 investment projects (worth approximately USD 1B investments). Furthermore, other CSA technologies and approaches were mainstreamed by various stakeholders as recommended in the MCSAS, such as the Climate-Smart Village(CSV) and climate-smart rice production.

title_project: [Gender and Social Inclusion] GSI: Engagement, synthesis and support in Gender
outcome_impact_statement: CCAFS facilitated and contributed text to the Africa Group of Negotiators (AGN) submission on the UNFCCC Gender Action Plan at the 46th Subsidiary Body for Implementation (SBI46) in May 2017 and country submissions from Ghana and Kenya; support was provided to the AGN Expert Support (AGNES) gender facilitator at the Gender Action Plan negotiations at COP25; technical support and text provided in the AGNES submission on Good Practices in Gender Mainstreaming of National Adaptation Plans and Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs).

title_oics: Reform of Ghana’s main agricultural mechanization program to better meet the needs of smallholder farmers
title_project: 2.1.2 Mechanization and Policies for Labor Saving Technology
outcome_impact_statement: IFPRI researchers, a CIMMYT engineer specialist and government officials from Ghana's Ministry of Food and Agriculture carried out an assessment of Ghana's Agricultural Mechanization Service Enterprise Center program. The recommendations from this assessment, taking into account good practices from other countries, were used by the government to improve the program’s inclusiveness and efficiency.

title_oics: Impact assessment of exclosure improvement in Amhara Region, Ethiopia
title_project: Activity 4.2.1: Improved environmental management options.

title_oics: Promotion of coffee-based agroforestry and women’s livelihoods in Vietnam
title_project: [Flagship Leader] FP3: Engagement, synthesis and support
outcome_impact_statement: In northwest Vietnam, women's unions in nine provinces and ten local NGOs used "Training for Trainers” materials developed by CCAFS partners in the World Agroforestry Center (ICRAF) and CARE International to empower women and strengthen 65 Village Savings and Loan Associations in the production and marketing of coffee. More than 10,000 farmers have been trained to date, with a potential impact of ~1 Mt carbon sequestration on 20,000 ha and 350,000 indirect beneficiaries, 50% of which are ethnic minority women.

title_oics: Public and private sector takes Climate-Smart Village scaling to next level in India and Nepal
title_project: [Regional Program Leader] SA:  Scaling-up Strategies for Climate Risk Management in South Asian Agriculture
scope_comments: States in Indian and Nepal.
outcome_impact_statement: State governments in India/Nepal and private sector corporates in India are increasingly giving emphasis on scaling of Climate Smart Villages (CSVs) for building climate-resilient agriculture. The scaling activities through government efforts build on existing CSVs and the new initiatives are either focusing on increased investments and expanding it to new villages. The private sector initiatives in India focus on working with ITC limited, Reliance Foundation and Sonalika Foundation. The impact assessment of CSV projects is also being done.

title_project: [Regional Program Leader] SEA: Regional and National synthesis, engagement and support
outcome_impact_statement: Through CCAFS outputs and capacity building activities, the key officials and staff of at least eight offices under the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (MARD) enhanced their knowledge, skills, and favorable attitude towards climate-smart agriculture (CSA). This has enabled the mainstreaming of CCAFS outputs and inputs in the national policies (e.g. Resolution-120, Nationally Determined Contributions(NDC), UNFCCC-SBSTA submissions) and key programs (i.e., New Rural Development Program, National Adaptation Plan in Agriculture(NAPAg), Sustainable Agricultural Transformation, and the Rice Master Plan).
