title_oics: Experimental games scaled out to 250,000 households to improve ground and surface water governance in India
title_project: 5.2.1 Governing Shared Landscapes
outcome_impact_statement: In India, rapid decline in groundwater levels is a serious challenge in many areas. With support from PIM and WLE, IFPRI partnered with the Foundation for Ecological Security, a major Indian NGO, to develop and test the use of experimental games to strengthen groundwater governance at the community level. ICRISAT developed similar tools for managing surface water. These tools are being scaled out to over 3,700 communities involving some 250,000 households in at least six Indian states.

title_oics: Investigating the outcome-orientation of Climate Change Program (success factors, failures, etc.)
title_project: [Program Management Unit] CCAFS Comms and Core Partnerships for Scaling CSA

title_oics: WLE/ICRAF soil spectral technology impacting soil restoration strategies and investments are being scaled up from Africa to global use
title_project: Scaling soil-plant spectral technology for targeting and monitoring land restoration and agricultural intensification in Africa and Asia
scope_comments: This began as an Africa-focused program but has now gone global.
outcome_impact_statement: WLE/ICRAF’s soil spectroscopy initiatives have moved from African outcomes to achieving global outcomes. Growing donor interest in deploying low-cost soil spectral technology in agricultural projects for better evidence-based investments is leading to major investments in India, Haiti, and elsewhere. WLE and the Food and Agriculture Organization-led Global Soil Laboratory Network are leading a new initiative to develop a free global soil mid-infrared spectral library and prediction service in collaboration with the Kellogg Soil Survey Laboratory in the United States.

title_oics: WLE/Bioversity influenced the Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES) to focus on critical interdependencies of biodiverse ecosystems and food production
scope_comments: There are 134 IPBES member states.
outcome_impact_statement: Building on its scientific work, WLE influenced the Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES) to focus on the critical interdependencies of biodiverse ecosystems and food production. The 134 IPBES countries have adopted WLE's proposal to focus its Nexus Assessment on Biodiversity, Food, Health and Water. It will identify nature-based solutions integrating agriculture and biodiversity to support both human health and environmental sustainability. WLE is positioned as a principal contributor to agricultural policy developments in the next decade.

title_oics: With strong WLE/Bioversity support, the EAT Lancet Commission study is transforming international food system and dietary guidelines for health and sustainability
outcome_impact_statement: With four senior scientist co-authors, the CGIAR was a major contributor to the EAT-Lancet Commission’s ground-breaking comprehensive review defining a universal healthy diet. It also show how agriculture, currently the primary cause and victim of environmental degradation, is also our best bet for solving hunger, health and sustainability. The report is having a profound influence on the international development discourse and has set the stage for the work of the WLE Commission on the Sustainable Intensification of Agriculture.

title_oics: The adoption of happy-seeder technology by 0.5 million farm-households on 1.3 million hectares in north-west India contributed to increased yields, profits, water and nutrient saving.
title_project: [Regional Program Leader] SA:  Scaling-up Strategies for Climate Risk Management in South Asian Agriculture
scope_comments: Punjab and Haryana, National Capital Region of Delhi, Western Uttar Pradesh
outcome_impact_statement: In continuation of CCAFS outcome reported during 2017 and 2018, significant efforts made during 2019 through science evidence mediated enabling environments, enhanced capacity and community awareness through innovative partnerships and investments, lead to significantly increased adoption of no-burn, happy seeder technology reaching 1.3 million hectares of north-west India and to more than ~0.5 million farmers. However, urban and rural beneficiary population due to reduced air pollution are quite significant and estimated at 50 million.

title_oics: Building community prosperity through scaling out WLE/ICRISAT agricultural water management interventions for sustainable crop intensification in Central India
title_project: Analyzing impact of various Agricultural Water Management Interventions on watershed hydrology and various ecosystem trade-offs in Bundelkhand region of Central India
scope_comments: This project focuses on the Bundelkhand region in Central India
outcome_impact_statement: Water harvesting and productivity interventions implemented by WLE/ICRISAT and the Central Agroforestry Research Institute on a pilot watershed in central India had significant impacts on water resources, incomes and farmers' livelihoods. As a result, the Government of Uttar Pradesh has asked ICRISAT and a consortium of national partners to scale the model out to over 35,000 ha.

title_oics: Evaluation of Gender Integration in FTA
title_project: 10. Gender

title_oics: Private sector partnership increased adoption of Aflasafe, reducing aflatoxin accumulation and improving net incomes for smallholders in Nigeria
title_project: Policy engagement to build awareness of opportunities for mitigating and controlling aflatoxins in informal markets
outcome_impact_statement: Impact evaluation of an IITA-implemented project found that the project created a niche premium market for Aflasafe-treated (AT) maize in Nigeria. The AgResults project incentivized private agribusinesses to work with smallholder farmers to adopt Aflasafe. The project stimulated exponential Aflasafe uptake and increased each smallholder’s net income from maize by $318 and use of AT maize as food by 13%. The main limitation to creation of a larger market for AT maize was awareness of aflatoxin and its health risks.

title_oics: Ex-Ante Impact Assessment of the project Provision of Adequate Tree Seed Portfolios in Ethiopia (PATSPO)
title_project: 1.  Restoration (forest and landscape restoration)

title_oics: ASEAN Guidelines for Agroforestry Development set to revolutionize land use in Southeast Asia
title_project: 9. Landscape Governance
outcome_impact_statement: Ministers on Agriculture and Forestry of the Association of South East Asian Nations endorse Guidelines for Agroforestry Development, developed by ICRAF. The adoption of the guidelines paves the way for implementation to restore degraded landscapes, improve food security and livelihoods, enhance farmers resilience and meet nationally determined contributions to climate-change targets.

title_oics: WLE/Bioversity International support development of new National Seed Policy aimed at agricultural transformation in Uganda
title_project: Assessment and use of agricultural biodiversity for landscape and ecosystem restoration

title_oics: WLE/ICRAF co-led report with recommendations on soil carbon management and monitoring accepted by the UNCCD Conference of the Parties
title_project: Land Health Evaluation

title_oics: Nepal’s National Irrigation Master Plan adopts WLE/IWMI water availability calculations and tools
title_project: Sustainable Water Resources Development in Western Nepal Through Ensuring Resilient Freshwater Ecosystem Services (Digo Jal Bikas)
outcome_impact_statement: Nepal’s Department of Water Resources and Irrigation (DWRI) has incorporated into its new National Irrigation Master Plan hydrological models of four river basins and a desktop tool for Environmental Flows (E-flows) assessment developed by IWMI. This is the first time irrigation planning is based on hydrological modeling of entire river basins to account for upstream/downstream linkages and multiple water uses, and the first-time assessment of E-flows are included. It will transform future irrigation planning in Nepal.

title_oics: WLE/ICRISAT integrates smart water management tools and Innovation Platforms in small-scale Zimbabwean irrigation schemes to deliver enhanced water productivity, incomes, and conflict reduction
title_project: Irrigation water management for food security and income generation in smallholder farming systems
scope_comments: The project is regional, but the story is only on Zimbabwe.
outcome_impact_statement: The combined use of Agricultural Innovation Platforms and smart water management tools in two small-scale communal irrigation schemes in Zimbabwe, resulted in major improvements in water and land productivity, household incomes, and reductions in conflict levels. As a result, the Director of Irrigation with support from the Australian Council for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR) agreed to fund a second project that is extending the model to 30 more irrigation schemes, covering 757 ha and 1698 farmers.

title_oics: WLE/CIAT facilitated development and approval of the first municipal food security policy for Cali (Colombia) to support an integrated action plan
title_project: Assessing the resilience and environmental sustainability of the Cali city region food system
outcome_impact_statement: As a result of CIAT/WLE efforts since 2015, in 2019 the City of Cali, Colombia, adopted a comprehensive municipal food security policy. It emerged from research and consultations among multiple stakeholders, and is designed to improve the food security of the poorest consumers in Cali and surrounding regions. Workshops with other municipalities is likely to assist them to adopt a similar plan.

title_oics: WLE/IWMI research and capacity building to support sustainable groundwater development and management in Laos influences policies and implementation programs
title_project: Sustainable Groundwater
outcome_impact_statement: Research carried out by WLE/IWMI supported by the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR) has had significant influence on groundwater management policies and practice in Laos. Laos adopted specific recommendations of the research for its national groundwater action plan, scaled out piloted sub-national groundwater management plans to other areas, used research results as inputs to a revised law on water resources, and included research findings in the draft national groundwater irrigation strategy.

title_oics: A refined method for theory-based evaluation of the societal impacts of research
title_project: 21. Quality of FTA research for development

title_oics: Nepal becomes the second country in the world to have a national agroforestry policy, with support from ICRAF
title_project: 9. Landscape Governance
outcome_impact_statement: Nepal's national agroforestry policy, developed with technical support from ICRAF, is expected to eliminate the barriers faced by farmers in harvesting, transporting and selling their agroforestry products and will be key to improving the livelihoods of smallholders and in enhancing their resilience to climate change. The policy-development process is an outcome of a national consultation organised jointly by the Government of Nepal and ICRAF that resulted in the 2015 Kathmandu Declaration on Agroforestry.

title_oics: Engagement strategy has seen FTA's research and recommendations inform the gender-responsive design and implementation of global policy processes
title_project: 10. Gender
scope_comments: The recommendations will inform guidelines and policy documents produced as part of the UNFCCC and the CBD global processes and will apply to all parties signatories of these conventions.
outcome_impact_statement: FTA recommendations shape the design and implementation of global policy processes. The program's gender research  has influenced the design of policy documents produced in the negotiation processes in the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD), and FTA recommendations on gender indicators for SDG13 on climate change were incorporated in the "Equal Measures 2030" global report

title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard

title_oics: Sustainability assessment of smallholder´s farming system: Assessment of the impacts of sustainable intensification options
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard

title_oics: Tropical Legumes III Project
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard

title_oics: Review of scaling approaches applied in GLDC scaling projects: Tropical Legumes III, Harnessing Opportunities for Productivity Enhancement 2, Feed the Future initiatives and DryDev
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard

title_oics: Identify a common set of performance indicators that all projects can report on at the CRP level beyond the CGIAR ones
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard

title_oics: Pan Africa Bean Research Alliance
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard

title_oics: Ensure real-time data visualization based on conceptualized indicator framework: CGIAR Level Agricultural Results Interoperable System Architecture (CLARISA)
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard

title_oics: Ex post evaluation of integrated soil fertility Management
title_project: Increasing yield potential, stress tolerance and input use  efficiency of highland maize varieties in Eastern and Southern Africa
scope_comments: data collected from Northern Ghana and Western Kenya and showed that the technology adoption leads to grain yield increase by up to 27% Northern Ghana and 16% in Western Kenya.

title_oics: Ugandan farmers adopting techniques to control Xanthomonas wilt of banana (BXW) have restored the productivity of their fields and their incomes
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Farmers in East Africa are adopting practices to control BXW. The results of the first nationally relevant study on the adoption of BXW control practices in Uganda was published and provides information about numbers of adopters, practices adopted and estimates of benefits linked with adoption. 600,000 is the number of households that have adopted at least some of the BXW control practices. Adoption of these practices is higher on subsistence farmers. Productivity and economic benefits are higher on larger farms.

title_oics: Seed Tracker used by National Plant Protection Organizations (NPPOs) to support national certification schemes in Nigeria and Tanzania
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Most cassava seed traded in informal markets in Sub-Saharan Africa has neither quality nor varietal identity of the planting material guaranteed. Contaminated material contributes to the spread of diseases resulting in low yields. IITA scientists developed ‘Seed Tracker’, a web-app that registers certified seed producers, allows e-certification of seed, and supports value chain development. The seed certifying authorities of Nigeria and Tanzania have adopted ‘Seed Tracker’, thus greatly increasing the efficiency of seed certification.

title_oics: Using biofortified sweetpotato to fight micronutrient malnutrition among vulnerable populations in sub-Sahara Africa
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: A multi-partner coalition led by CIP contributed to the release of 150 improved sweetpotato varieties, 100 of them orange-fleshed, with high levels of vitamin A, across 17 countries of SSA. In total vines of improved varieties were distributed to more than 6.2 M households potentially reaching 29 million individuals.

title_oics: Nuru mobile phone app is being scaled out to help farmers identify and manage cassava diseases
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Farmers and extensionists find it hard to correctly identify cassava diseases. Based upon research with RTB using artificial intelligence and Google’s TensorFlow technology the mobile app Nuru has been developed. This has been downloaded over 1,000 times and is being used by farmers in Kenya and elsewhere to improve the management of these diseases.

title_oics: Farmer Business Schools help in creating and diversifying livelihood opportunities for women and men farmers in Asian agri-food systems
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: After satisfactory implementation in the Philippines, the Farmer Business School approach has been adopted by national development programs supported by IFAD investments in four Asian countries. Using a qualitative approach, the initial most significant changes promoted through this approach were documented: improved organization of farmer groups, enhanced business skills at the individual and group level, promotion of gender equity, emergence of new food security and income opportunities linked with the improved production and processing techniques, better linkage to local markets.

title_oics: Agriculture-nutrition education and extension programs foster the adoption of biofortified crops in Kenya
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Intensive agriculture-nutrition education and extension variables significantly increased early adoption of orange-fleshed sweetpotato (OFSP) varieties in an intervention in Kenya. 75.7% of respondents in a large survey reported planting OFSP varieties one year later.

title_oics: National Agricultural Research Systems (NARS) in partner countries are using BreeDBases, a comprehensive management software, to modernize and enhance their breeding programs
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Digitization of data is essential for the modernization of breeding programs. It allows for the standardization of trait descriptions and levels, makes data access easier and more shareable, and reduces errors. In a collaboration with the Boyce Thomson Institute, databases have been set up for sweetpotato, cassava, banana, and yam, all accessible through BreeDBase, a comprehensive breeding management and analysis software. National breeding programs in partner countries have been trained in its use and are now managing trials through BreeDBase.

title_oics: Small RNA sequencing and VirusDetect a bioinformatics pipeline that assist in the detection of known and new and novel viruses is being used beyond RTB
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: CIP invented small RNA sequencing and assembly, a universal virus detection tool, and with partners have developed VirusDetect, a bioinformatics pipeline that can assist in the detection of all known, but also new and novel viruses. This will enable improved management of viruses including rapid identification of emerging diseases, safe movement of germplasm and incorporation of resistance into breeding lines. VirusDetect has already been downloaded 22 times from the website, and has been applied and recognized in several publications.

title_oics: Assessing global evidence base of impact of interventions to promote agroforestry
title_project: 14. Agroecology

title_oics: Reach and early adoption of agroecological practices promoted by RySS across the state of Andhra Pradesh.
title_project: 14. Agroecology
scope_comments: Report submitted to funder (APPI) and development partner (RySS)

title_oics: Evaluation of EU/IFAD dryland restoration research in East and West Africa
title_project: 1.  Restoration (forest and landscape restoration)

title_oics: Soil erosion prevalence baseline for North Western Vietnam
title_project: 1.  Restoration (forest and landscape restoration)
scope_comments: results presented at mid-term review of AFLi-2 project in April

title_oics: The declaration of Nijhum Dwip Marine Protected Area (MPA) to generate more sustainable fishing and livelihoods while protecting the marine biodiversity in Bangladesh
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: WorldFish achieved success in facilitating the declaration of a 3,188 km2 Marine Protected Area (MPA) to protect hilsa (a kind of Indian herring fish) breeding and nursery grounds as well as habitats for marine fish, crustaceans, megafauna and migratory birds. This will ensure a higher production of hilsa that will benefit to the livelihoods of more than 0.45 million hilsa-dependent households, and contribute to meeting the country’s commitments to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goal 14 to conserve marine waters.

title_oics: Governing Myanmar’s Inland Fisheries: towards a more sustainable fish production and inclusive benefit-sharing among fish-dependent communities
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: The FISH research findings  in Myanmar have accompanied an important political move towards the legal recognition of community based fisheries management (CBFM ) as a more suitable alternative to the auction system. The research activities are contributing to making the co-management of fisheries more inclusive and participatory for a more equitable distribution of benefits. The power of influence of the research activities in the decentralization process, can generate great impact once the new policies are introduced and applied nation-wide.

title_oics: The adoption of aquaculture Best Management Practices to benefit the livelihoods and nutrition of more than 2,000 Women Self-Help Groups in Odisha, India
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: During 2019 total, 2,429  Gram Panchayat (GP) tanks with water spread area of 1,877 Ha were leased out to 2,400 Women Self Help Groups to carry out pisciculture across 30 districts of Odisha. In more than 40% of the GP tanks managed by WSHGs, the WSHGs operated their ponds by themselves without much support from male persons of their households. WSHGs became aware on nutrition-sensitive fish food systems through carp-mola polyculture practices.

title_oics: A nutrition-sensitive polyculture project improves dietary diversity among women and children in North-Eastern Bangladesh
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: More 44,256 beneficiary households have received support on nutrition sensitive aquaculture and fisheries under  "Suchana: Ending the Cycle of Under nutrition in Bangladesh" project.  Improved aquaculture and nutrition practices have contributed towards  the achievement of improvement of dietary diversity for 55, 887 individuals of which more than 40%  within the reproductive age and children 6-24 months group, and 38% in the adolescent group.

title_oics: More than 12,000 fish producers in Bangladesh adopt improved pond management practices
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: 12,475 fish producers in Bangladesh (8,471 women of which 2,563 are between 15-29 years) have applied improved pond management practices, developed by WorldFish, in their ponds. In total, 2,086 hectares of pond area in Bangladesh have been under improved management as a result of the intervention enabled by the USAID funded "Feed the future Nutrition Activity - Bangladesh" project.

title_oics: The first public-private-partnership (PPP) model tilapia hatchery in Timor-Leste boosted the country’s production of GIFT fingerlings and paved the way for the aquaculture sector’s sustainability
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Public-private partnership in  genetically improved farmed tilapia (GIFT) seed production and dissemination helped in narrowing supply – demand gap for seed of 300 fish farmers in Timor Leste and will help towards achieving the National Aquaculture Development Strategy (2012—2030) targets, which aims to boost fish supply from aquaculture to 12,000 tons and reduce undernourishment by increasing per capita consumption of fish from 6.1 to 15.0 kg by 2030.

title_oics: Successful establishment of the of GIFT Satellite Breeding Program in India with more than 4,000 grow-out farmers
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Rajiv Gandhi Center for Aquaculture (RGCA)  Government of India and WorldFish have successfully established GIFT (Genetically Improved Farmed Tilapia) Satellite Breeding Program . Since 2016, 21.45 million mono-sex GIFT fry from RGCA was distributed to 3,575 farmers who produced 10,725 metric tons of GIFT and sold in local market. Also, 4.365 million mono-sex GIFT fry from other hatcheries were sold to 728 farmers who produced 2,178 metric tons of GIFT and sold in local market.

title_oics: The better management practices (BMPs) for Genetically Improved Farmed Tilapia (GIFT) in Timor-Leste help to realize the potential of aquaculture in the country
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: The FISH Research program in collaboration with the Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries (MAF) has successfully developed  contextualized Best Management Guidelines (BMPs) resources at the country level to support support scaling of GIFT sustainably to improve nutrition, food security and rural livelihoods . Farmers that have followed the BMPs guidelines reported an increased total production and productivity, which  has directly contributed to their household food, nutrition, and income.

title_oics: Small fish as nutrition add on in school feeding program in Odisha, India
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: The project has introduced small fish in 24 institutional feeding program for a total 2336 children from 11 Child Care institutions and 13 special schools. The pilot feeding trials carried out in these institutions has influenced the management of Kalinga Institute of Social Science (KISS) to allow piloting of small fish in their Mega kitchen, which feeds 30,000 tribal children in Odisha.

title_oics: Dissemination of nutrition-sensitive aquaculture technologies and practices generate income and nutrition benefits for small-scale farmers in some of  Myanmar's poorest areas
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Small-scale aquaculture has significant potential to diversify livelihoods, raise incomes and improve household food security through greater access to fresh, nutritious fish. Since 2017, Myanmar Sustainable Aquaculture Programme (MYSAP Inland) has worked on this direction to support 1,264 households of which at least 1,450 women of reproductive age and 440 children under 5. The project has focused on the dissemination of nutrition-sensitive aquaculture technologies and practices to generate a regular source of income and fish for consumption  by small-scale farmers.

title_oics: Emergent aquaculture technologies in Myanmar: opportunities and key outcomes
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: In Myanmar, 3,654 households direct households have adopted improved management practices and technologies in their ponds. Money generated from ponds has helped household's finances, clearly indicated by the role of aquaculture in the total income of households.  Aquaculture has become an important source of income. The value of income gained by the overall direct beneficiaries was USD 900,000.  Over 10,000 households that indirectly benefited via awareness raising and exposure to knowledge, sharing and learning

title_oics: An holistic approach in disseminating CGIAR technologies and  innovations to boost the efficiency of agriculture production systems in Malawi
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: CGIAR Centers in Malawi are providing expertise and relevant innovations and technologies to farmers. The Centers provide relevant innovations and technologies with the intent to address a holistic manner the issues affecting agricultural production systems in Malawi. By the end of the project, over 400,000 rural households will diversify their diets by including intake of high quality proteins and micro-nutrients from fish.

title_oics: Promoting adoption of integrated agriculture and aquaculture production systems in Malawi
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: In view of improving skills and knowledge of farmers and agri-business capacity to allow them contributing actively to sustainable growth leading to improved food, nutrition and income security KULIMA has addressed the outlined challenges by increasing agricultural productivity. This action tackles diversification of production systems and yields increase through adequate input and large scale adoption of integrated farming practices through relevant knowledge and influence on current practices of farmers. More than 3000 community facilitators have been trained reaching 90,000 farmers.

title_oics: How rice field fisheries are netting nutrition gains for over 124,876 people  in Cambodia
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: WorldFish research shows that well-managed community fish refuges (CFRs) can significantly improve fish productivity of the rice field environment as soon as one year after the intervention. WorldFish monitoring shows that in one year, the amount of fish caught has increased by 30 percent, and the proportion of young children under five eating small fish increased by 50%. Over 124,876 people in Cambodia consumed more fish at home following behavior change interventions associated with enhanced rice field fish productivity .

title_oics: Community Savings Schemes  Financially Empower Coastal Fisher Women in Bangladesh
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: The ECOFISH project has established at least one community savings group (CSG) with 30-35 women in each fishing village of intervention comprising 148 community savings groups involving 4,125 women with a total savings of USD 159,210. This novel approach has led to women empowerment for providing collateral free soft loan among themselves. So far, 1,770 women have received the loans from this fund, each in two to three times, and reinvested in different small businesses

title_oics: Hilsa Production and Fishers’ Income Increased due to co-management strategies aimed to enhance the socio-economic resilience of fishing communities in Bangladesh
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: The co-management interventions helped in producing 6% extra annual incremental production that comprised about 130,000 tons hilsa over last 3 years, with a worth about US$1,040 million. As a result of the increased hilsa production and improved hilsa size, the total household fishers’ income and income from fishing activities have been increased by 65% and 67%, respectively. 4,257 Hilsa fishing households have been fully engaged in sound and sustainable Alternative Income Generating (AIGAs) as  strategy to improve co-management.

title_oics: The Government of Myanmar extends the promotion of  integrated farming systems to accommodate more  fish for smallholder farmers
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: The land-use policy reform process, which started on 8 August 2018 with the Naypyitaw agreement to allow integrated agriculture for rice-fish production, has now been taken a step further with the agreement, in the Ayeyarwady Region, that up to 15% of a farmer’s rice-field area can be converted into fish holding refuges for integrated rice-fish production systems. Using better management practices for rice, fish and water are shown to increase rice yield, profitability, employment options for youth and women .

title_oics: Fiscal reform: Design of a incentive-based system of hilsa fisheries management in Myanmar’s Ayeyarwady Delta  for more sustainable and inclusive fisheries
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Research activities on socio-economics, biology and ecology of hilsa fishery in Myanmar are providing evidence to the Government in reviewing its fiscal reforms strategy to mobilise and tailor additional resources towards financing a system of incentive-based hilsa fisheries management.The proposed fiscal reforms could generate annual revenues of USD 91.2 million per year for the government of Myanmar. This would contribute  better target actors nearer the top of the hilsa value chain and support more sustainable and inclusive hilsa fisheries.

title_oics: Rural outmigration – feminization – agricultural production nexus: Case of Vietnam
title_project: IRRI Contribution to RICE Flagship Project 1

title_oics: National adoption of small-scale fisheries data system in Timor-Leste
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: The PeskAAS digital fisheries monitoring system developed with and for the government of Timor-Leste to more effectively gather data on catch and distribution of fishing effort, has been officially launched and adopted by the Government as of May 2019. The partnership with Pelagic Data Systems enabled the rapid scaling of the system to 500 vessel tracking devices involving 5000 fishers. The data will contribute to guide the sustainable exploitation of these resources  influencing the livelihoods of smalls-scale coastal fishers.

title_oics: Rapid generation advancement (RGA): enabling speed breeding in chickpea, and lentil
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Rapid Generation Advancement (RGA) protocols enabled the rapid generation of homozygous lines & increased the number of crop generations per year, enhancing the rate of genetic gain and reducing the varietal breeding time from 12 years to 6 years. Fast-tracking of breeding pipelines will allow ICRISAT, ICARDA, & partner breeding institutions to deliver faster with higher resource use efficiency, and expedite the release of improved chickpea and lentil cultivars.

title_project: Building foresight portfolio for MAIZE AFS, including synthesis, gap analysis and new studies, as input in conducting priority setting for MAIZE AFS

title_oics: High oleic groundnut varieties commercialized in India meet the enhanced shelf-life needs of food industry and consumer health benefits.
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: High oleic groundnut varieties are preferred by food processing industry for enhanced shelf-life benefits and has consumer health benefits. The process innovations in breeding and testing pipeline resulted in commercialisation of high oleic cultivars in India in 8-years of time as against the normal 12-15 years. The partnership between the national program in India and ICRISAT, and long-term donor support was critical for the success. ICRISAT has shared the high oleic lines  with nine countries in Africa and Asia.

title_oics: Improved cowpea varieties contribute to poverty reduction in Nigeria
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: IITA and its partners have developed and promoted improved cowpea varieties that are high yielding, resistant to striga, alectra, and insect pests, and drought tolerant. This has resulted in the release over 20 improved cowpea varieties in Nigeria since the early 1980’s. About 42% of the farmers have adopted improved cowpea varieties resulting into a 26% increase in yields, 14% decrease in production costs, 61% increase in net returns per hectare and 5 percentage point reduction in poverty incidence.

title_oics: TPE and beyond: laying the base for modern geography-specific crop improvement methodologies across CGIAR and partnering institutions
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: 1.Within the scope of the project, efforts were made to use crop modelling frameworks and high-throughput computational technologies to quantitatively analyze the cereal-based semi-arid tropical agri-systems in South Asia and sub-Saharan Africa and provide the data-driven advisory on optimum GxExM (genotype-by-management-by-environment) for current and projected climates. 2. The project outputs comprehensively visualized and enabled through the web-based applications that enable end-users, primarily the crop improvement programs (initially sorghum), to develop data driven, more robust and future looking breeding . https://maps.csita.cz/

title_oics: Improved Myanmar Chickpea Production through Early Maturing Cultivars
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: The introduction and subsequent adoption of ICRISAT sourced early maturing chickpea cultivars generated economic benefits estimated at US$152.8 million.

title_oics: Efficient Legume Seed Systems for Better Smallholder Farmers’ Livelihoods in the Semi-Arid Tropics
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Tropical Legumes (TL) Project together with precursor and complementary projects facilitated the development of 304 nutrient dense, climate-smart, farmer- and market-preferred varieties and the production of 397,050 t (t) of certified and quality declared seeds (QDS). The seed was planted on about 4.4 million hectares (ha) by more than 22 million smallholder farmers in the 15 target countries and beyond, producing about 4.9 million t of grain worth US$ 2.6 billion.

title_oics: Climbing bean technologies helped 0.8 M farming households increase productivity and food security, resulting to about 5,000 households climbing out of poverty in land-constrained Rwanda
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Bean growers in Rwanda often have less than a hectare to maintain a family. An ex-post impact assessment demonstrated that adopting households reap benefits from the climbing beans introduced by the international Center for Tropical Agriculture and the project, Pan African Bean Research Alliance (PABRA) more than 20 years ago as a means to intensify bean cultivation. Approximately 4.4 million people have raised their consumption expenditure, bean consumption and food security, while 0.6% of them are lifted out from poverty.

title_oics: Options by context approach to agronomic innovation profoundly changed International, Government, NGO and private sector policy and practice across 14 countries.
title_project: 14. Agroecology
outcome_impact_statement: FTA produced a paradigm shift in agronomy supporting local innovation across three continents.  Diverse and inclusive agroecological options that result, impact food security, farm income and environmental resilience for over 3.769 M people on 2.496 M ha and are part of global initiatives targeting 100 M smallholder farmers.

title_project: Era study conducted on released/recommended CIMMYT’s LOWLAND TROPICAL MAIZE parental inbred lines and single crosses.

title_oics: FTA Research informs the development of a Monitoring and Evaluation System for Vietnam's national Payment for Forest Environmental Services (PFES) system
title_project: 5.  NDCs - the central mechanism for climate policy under the Paris Agreement
outcome_impact_statement: A comprehensive Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) mechanism for PFES will enable policy makers to assess the effectiveness of such policies, as well as to demonstrate effectiveness to investors in order to secure sustainable funding. The new web-based M&E platform has been rolled out in the Lam Dong, Thanh Hoa, and Son La provinces and is expected too be deployed nationwide in 2020.

title_oics: Ten-Year Uganda National Bamboo Strategy and Action Plan enabled by Research from FTA
title_project: 13.  Farm-forest policy interface
outcome_impact_statement: Scientific evidence generated and demonstration model developed by the International Bamboo and Rattan Organisation’s (INBAR) Dutch-Sino East Africa Bamboo Development Programme and joint INBAR/FTA research informed Uganda authorities of the significance and contribution of bamboo to sustainable development. Through using this research, and with technical and financial support from INBAR, the Ten-Year National Bamboo Strategy and Action Plan was commissioned, developed and written by the Ministry of Water and Environment of Uganda. This Action Plan is an important step to boosting the development of a viable and sustainable bamboo industry in the country.

title_oics: Changes in participation of women in rice value chains: Implications for control over decision making
title_project: IRRI Contribution to RICE Flagship Project 1

title_oics: Climate services for protection against wheat blast in Bangladesh
outcome_impact_statement: This Wheat Blast Early Warning System can be used by farmers to protect their wheat crops from wheat blast. This system has been completed and is reaching >850 extension agents regularly with updated blast advisories. The system has been adopted and endorsed by Bangladesh's Department of Agricultural Extension, Meteorological Department, and Bangladesh Wheat and Maize Research Institute.

title_oics: Legume-based rotations have clear economic advantages over cereal monocropping in dry areas
Research and policy communication efforts by CGIAR Research Program on Wheat scientists directly contributed to a Government of Zimbabwe Climate Smart Agriculture Framework
outcome_impact_statement: The Farm Mechanization and Conservation Agriculture for Sustainable Intensification (FACASI) project contributed to a national climate smart agriculture policy for Zimbabwe - through targeted research and communication on the most effective approach for smallholder farmer adoption of climate smart agricultural practices in eastern and southern Africa.

title_project: IRRI Contribution to RICE Flagship Project 2

title_oics: Adoption of Laser land leveling in South East Asia
title_project: IRRI Contribution to RICE Flagship Project 2
outcome_impact_statement: The benefits of laser-guided land leveling has spread significantly across South East Asia. Much of its success is due to the strong public-private partnerships, verification in the partner countries and fostering the adoption through field demonstrations, training of stakeholders and support to local equipment supply chains. First users are machinery contract service providers and final users are farmers.  Private contract service providers have remarkably increased. The technology is included in national policies for rice self sufficiency.

title_oics: Combine harvesting: spreading success in South East Asia
title_project: IRRI Contribution to RICE Flagship Project 2
outcome_impact_statement: IRRI spearheaded facilitation of technology improvement and multi-sectoral collaboration through public-private partnerships. Activities involved assessment of harvesting systems and promotion of mechanized options to address labor shortage and high cost of traditional harvesting. Business models were established with special focus on marginalised groups, women and youth.Analysis of the existing harvesting system within a value chain context, harvesting and postharvest losses, identification and demonstration of mechanised options and stakeholder analysis conducted.Used Life Cycle assessment for sustainability criteria in different harvesting systems.

title_oics: 10-year engagement with Kenyan Agriculture and Environment Ministries leads to uptake of climate smart agriculture practices by over 1 million farmers.
title_project: RPL EA: Regional and national engagement, synthesis and strategic research
scope_comments: Based on the experiences in Kenya, CCAFS and CGIAR partners are also supporting similar arrangements in the other CCAFS East Africa target countries - Ethiopia, Uganda and Tanzania.
outcome_impact_statement: Kenyan farmers are increasingly adopting climate-smart agriculture practices and technologies, bringing significant benefits in farm yields, livestock assets, and household welfare. CSA uptake has been spurred by CCAFS engagement with Kenyan Ministries over the past 10 years to support CSA adoption and implementation. CCAFS is a co-founding partner of the CSA Multi-Stakeholder Platform, aimed at coordinating and expanding CSA activities and investments in Kenya. It is estimated that 1,2 million farmers have adopted CSA practices in Kenya.

title_oics: Uptake of research-based recommendations to increase the impacts of Egypt’s national cash transfer program on the very poor
title_project: 4.1.2 Improving Design and Delivery of Social protection for Nutrition and Other Outcomes
outcome_impact_statement: In response to research-based recommendations, Egypt’s Ministry of Social Solidarity made several changes to the Takaful and Karama cash transfer program: the targeting methodology was adjusted to reach more beneficiaries, the public communications around the program was improved, and expanded collaboration with other ministries turned Takaful and Karama into the centre-piece of a new national social protection system.

title_oics: Adoption and impact survey of Smart-Valleys approach
title_project: Climate-smart rice technologies to enhance resilience of smallholder rice farmers in Burkina Faso

title_oics: Evaluating the boundary conditions for large scale adoption of alternate wetting and drying in Burkina Faso
title_project: Climate-smart rice technologies to enhance resilience of smallholder rice farmers in Burkina Faso

title_oics: The effects of Alternate Wetting and Drying (AWD) on water use, rice production and weed infestation in four irrigated rice systems in Burkina Faso
title_project: Climate-smart rice technologies to enhance resilience of smallholder rice farmers in Burkina Faso

title_oics: Rwanda Climate Services for Agriculture: Evaluation of farmers’ awareness, use and impacts
title_project: Climate Services for Agriculture: Empowering Farmers to Manage Risk and Adapt to a Changing Climate in Rwanda

title_oics: Research and technologies to improve agricultural productivity while guaranteeing environmental sustainability in five crops uptaken by Green growth policy in Colombia implemented with US$74.5 million
title_project: [Regional Program Leader] LAM: Local to National/Regional synthesis, research and engagement
outcome_impact_statement: In 2018, CCAFS and partners provided technical and policy recommendations on Land Productivity and Agricultural Performance for the Colombian Green Growth Policy. The government allocated US $74.5 million to implement actions that help to improve the agricultural sector's performance aiming for increasing by 3%, the agricultural production under green-growth criteria. The current National Development Plan focuses on sustainable agricultural activities that include climate-smart innovation options in line with green growth standards.

title_oics: Volunteer Farmer Trainer program reaching 352,000 dairy farmers in Uganda increases knowledge and productivity
title_project: 1.2.2 Agricultural Extension and Advisory Services
outcome_impact_statement: Since 2012, PIM has supported efforts by ICRAF and partners to implement the volunteer farmer trainer approach in Eastern Africa. As of 2018, 86 organizations across Eastern Africa have adopted the volunteer farmer trainer approach. These organizations work with 17,600 volunteer farmer trainers and serve 352,000 farmers. An impact evaluation found that the use of this approach improved farmers’ knowledge of dairy practices as well as dairy productivity and revenues in Uganda’s Busoga region.

title_oics: Insect-resistant cotton approved for release to farmers in Malawi and planted by 20,000 farmers during the first growing season
title_project: 1.2.4 Comparative Science, Technology, and Innovation Systems in Developing-Country Agriculture
outcome_impact_statement: Following several years of confined field trials and on-farm trials to test the safety and performance of Bt cotton hybrid varieties, the Government of Malawi approved their release to farmers for the 2019-2020 season. 20,000 farmers planted it. The Program for Biosafety Systems provided technical support to the government throughout this process.

title_oics: Ethiopian Government incorporates scaling sustainable intensification of maize-based systems (agronomy at scale) into its extension system
title_project: Identify, analyze  and map key maize (a)biotic stresses in selected countries in SSA
outcome_impact_statement: Published research evidence were used to develop policy briefs and task forces, to engage policy makers at several levels in a series of workshops and meetings over years. The efforts resulted in the 2019 adoption of conservation agriculture-based sustainable intensification (CASI) as an extension package by the Ministry of Agriculture of Ethiopia, offering significant yield, income and time saving gains to smallholder farmers practising maize-legumes cropping systems, as well as climate change adaptation benefits.

title_oics: Direct Seed Marketing boosts seed availability and improves crop yields and commercialization in Ethiopia (26% increase in maize yield)
title_project: 3.2.3 Linking Smallholders to Dynamic Markets
outcome_impact_statement: Ethiopia’s Direct Seed Marketing (DSM) innovation, scaled up to 290 woredas and 1.5 million smallholder farmers in 2019, improved seed availability for maize, wheat, and teff and led to significantly positive effects on maize productivity (26% increase in yield) and commercialization (5% increase in the share of harvest sold).  PIM research had informed the scaling of DSM and a PIM team conducted an ex-post impact assessment of DSM in 2020.

title_oics: Adoption of smart-valley approach by rice producers in Benin, Togo, Nigeria, Liberia and Sierra Leone (Liberia and Sierra Leone are two new countries in 2020)
title_project: AfricaRice contribution to RICE Flagship Project 3
scope_comments: Smart Valley approach has also been expanded to Ghana, Burkina Faso, Liberia and Sierra Leone.
outcome_impact_statement: Adoption of smart-valley increased from 110 ha in 2012 to 474 ha in 2014. Recent evidence show the approach has reached 45,000 ha in Nigeria. In 2019, the total area increased to 1030.94 hectares in Benin and Togo and adopted by 6110 farmers. In Sierra Leone, the total area tracked was 179.3 hectares and adopted by 460 rice farmers. Results show that the impact of the smart-valley on the rice income is 439.65 US$/ha in Sierra Leone & Liberia

title_oics: Aflasafe Biocontrol Products to Reduce Aflatoxin in Maize and Groundnut are Registered in Ten African Countries and Available at 92 Distribution Points in Nine Countries
title_project: Technological and institutional innovations for assessing and mitigating food safety risks related to aflatoxins designed and tested, including capacity building
outcome_impact_statement: In 2020, Malawi became the tenth country where Aflasafe products are registered, bringing the total number of registered Aflasafe products to 14. Registration is critical for scale-up of Aflasafe. More private companies have started manufacturing and distributing Aflasafe products, making them available to thousands of farmers. To date, Aflasafe is available at 92 distribution points across nine countries. Private sector-led demonstrations have shown 98% effectiveness of Aflasafe in farmers’ fields in Nigeria. Companies are bringing Aflasafe closer to users.

title_oics: 14,900 farmers benefited from use of RiceAdvice in Nigeria in 2020 and this is equivalent to $2.8 million of gross revenue
title_project: AfricaRice contribution to RICE Flagship Project 3
scope_comments: RiceAdvice has also been dissemianted in Burkina Faso, Mali, and Senegal.
outcome_impact_statement: RiceAdvice is a free Android application that provides farm-specific advice on rice management practices to farmers. Impact assessment using randomized control trial in northern Nigeria showed that households who were just given the personalized advice increase their yield by 7% and increase their profit by 10%. On average, personalized advice increases yields without increasing the overall quantity of fertilizer used. In 2020, 14,900 farmers benefited from use of RiceAdvice and this is equivalent to $2.8 million of gross revenue.

title_oics: Implementation of regional rice value chain upgrading strategy in West Africa
title_project: IRRI Contribution to RICE Flagship Project 2
scope_comments: Eastern and Southern Africa
outcome_impact_statement: The policy sequencing strategy to upgrade rice value chains was disseminated to policy makers and contributed to the implementation of national rice development strategies.

title_oics: Using genetic diversity to manage shocks, improve livelihoods
title_project: Using biodiversity, including genetic diversity, for land restoration

title_oics: Solar suitability tool and maps developed by WLE/IWMI now used by private sector actors to expand solar pump supply chains across sub-Saharan Africa
title_project: On & off-grid Solar in Africa and Asia
scope_comments: Ghana and Ethiopia and Mozambique
outcome_impact_statement: A set of online interactive maps have been developed by WLE/IWMI to show the highest-potential locations for targeting small solar-powered irrigation pumps to smallholder farmers. Millions of farmers can substantially increase their incomes using these pumps. The tool is used to inform planning and management of sustainable solar pump irrigation dissemination in sub-Sahara Africa. Several project partners, i.e. solar manufacturing and distribution companies, are using the maps to expand their distribution and supply chains.

title_oics: WLE/CCAFS/IWMI support South Asia and sub-Saharan Africa to make the leap from drought monitoring to managing agricultural drought risks
title_project: Innovative Risk Management Solutions for Floods and Drought to support national strategies for Disaster Risk Reduction in South Asia
scope_comments: It is being implemented in 16 southern African countries. The South Asia part is the most salient at this point.
outcome_impact_statement: The South Asia Drought Monitoring System (SADMS) was created by WLE/IWMI with support from Japan’s Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, the Indian Council of Agricultural Research and CCAFS. Since 2018, SADMS has provided real-time drought severity data at the micro level to southern Indian states to inform drought contingency plans. Crop yields and incomes have been significantly higher than in the control areas. As a result, the SADMS framework has been scaled out to other Asian and African countries.

title_project: Improve winter wheat for farmer relevant traits

title_oics: Lessons learnt in CCAFS Flagship 4 Phase II
title_project: [Flagship Leader] FP4: Engagement, synthesis and support

title_oics: Dissemination and Adoption of Bundled Agronomic Practices in Vietnam, Benin, Togo, Nigeria and Brazil
title_project: IRRI Contribution to RICE Flagship Project 1
outcome_impact_statement:
In the previous two decades, members of the RICE CRP, including created and disseminated regionally-designed and locally-appropriate portfolios of agronomic practices in collaboration with local partners.  
we find that previously published levels of dissemination and adoption tend to be inflated. However, this
does not mean that the adoption of these technologies is limited. We document reliable sources of data on
adoption for each technology and, where appropriate, use these data to estimate adoption rates in the regions of interest.

title_oics: Participatory rangeland management (PRM) being piloted in Kenya and Tanzania covering 246,773 ha of pastoralists' communal grazing lands, and upscaled in Ethiopia (Updated 2020)
title_project: Activity 4.3.1: Land and resource tenure arrangements and institutional models.
scope_comments: Participatory rangeland management (PRM) following similar steps has also been implemented in Mongolia. There is potential to scale-up PRM elsewhere.
outcome_impact_statement: Participatory rangeland management (PRM) was developed by ILRI and partners in Ethiopia, piloted and then upscaled. PRM improves the productivity of rangelands and access to resources for local rangelands users (communities). In  2018, the European Union invested Euro 1.5 million in the Piloting of PRM Project in Baringo County, Kenya and six shared grazing lands in Tanzania (targeting 450,000 pastoralists and agropastoralists). In 2020/21 PRM is being upscaled through a USD 30 million investment on 8.8 million hectares in Ethiopia.

title_oics: Factors influencing gendered access to climate information services for farming in Senegal
title_project: [Flagship Leader] FP4: Engagement, synthesis and support

title_oics: Gender equality outcomes from Rwanda Climate Services for Agriculture project
title_project: [Flagship Leader] FP4: Engagement, synthesis and support

title_oics: Monitoring surveys for zinc wheat in India (Bihar)
title_project: Monitoring and learning for biofortification

title_oics: Seed Tracker a web-app that registers certified seed producers, allows e-certification of seed, and supports value chain development
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Most seed traded in informal markets in developing countries has neither quality nor varietal identity of the planting material guaranteed. Contaminated material contributes to the spread of diseases resulting in low yields. IITA scientists developed ‘Seed Tracker’, a web-app that registers certified seed producers, allows e-certification of seed, and supports value chain development. The seed certifying authorities of Nigeria and Tanzania have adopted ‘Seed Tracker’, greatly increasing the efficiency of seed certification, and in 2020 Brazil also adopted it.

title_oics: 130 Farmer Business Schools help in creating and diversifying livelihood opportunities for 3,500 women and men farmers in four asian countries
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: After satisfactory implementation in the Philippines, the Farmer Business School approach has been adopted by national development programs supported by IFAD investments in India, Indonesia, Vietnam and the Philippines. Using a qualitative approach, the most significant changes were documented: improved organization of farmer groups, enhanced business skills at the individual and group level, promotion of gender equity, emergence of new food security and income opportunities linked with the improved production and processing techniques, better linkage to local markets.

title_oics: The adoption of Aquaculture Best Management Practices by fisherwomen is contributing to livelihoods and nutrition improvements for nearly 200,000 people in Odisha, India
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Gram Panchayat (GP) tanks with water spread area of 3,516 hectares have been leased out to more than 4,500 Women Self Help Groups (WSHGs) to carry out pisciculture across 30 districts of Odisha. WorldFish has been providing technical support to the district officials in various implementation processes. WSHGs became aware on nutrition-sensitive fish food systems through carp-mola polyculture practices, and now over 45,000 women have adopted BMPs, contributing to nearly 200,000 people consuming more fish.

title_oics: Nutrition-sensitive polyculture intervention is providing  livelihood opportunities and nutrition gains for over 107,290 people in North-Eastern Bangladesh
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: More than 109,153 people have received support on nutrition sensitive aquaculture and fisheries under  "Suchana: Ending the Cycle of Under nutrition in Bangladesh" project in 2020.  Improved aquaculture and nutrition practices have contributed towards  increased fish consumption for  107,290 individuals of which more than 40%  within the reproductive age and children 6-23 months group, and 38% in the adolescent group.

title_oics: More than 111,470 fish producers in Bangladesh adopt improved pond management practices
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: FISH activities via  with funding from USAID under Feed the Future Bangladesh Aquaculture Activity (BAA) project in Bangladesh have led 111,469 households to apply improved pond management practices. As a result 34,875 hectares of pond area have are now under improved management.

title_oics: The Genetically Improved Farmed Tilapia (GIFT) has been disseminated to nearly 6,000 farmers in India thanks to the Satellite Breeding Program, established in collaboration with the Rajiv Gandhi Center for Aquaculture (RGCA)
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Rajiv Gandhi Center for Aquaculture (RGCA)  Government of India and WorldFish have successfully established GIFT (Genetically Improved Farmed Tilapia) Satellite Breeding Program . GIFT has been disseminated to nearly 6,000 farmers.  A dissemination and scaling strategy targeting a production of  2.4 million metric ton of tilapia by 2030 in the country is under way.

title_oics: The adoption of innovative aquaculture technologies and sustainable practices is improving nutrition and livelihoods for over 1,000 poor families in Myanmar
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Small-scale aquaculture has significant potential to diversify livelihoods, raise incomes and improve household food security through greater access to fresh, nutritious fish. Myanmar Sustainable Aquaculture Programme (MYSAP Inland) initiative has focused on aquaculture technologies and best practices for smallholder farmers. A total 1,176 households have improved management practices related to aquaculture and are stocking of small indigenous fish species (SIS) for household consumption. Fish productivity has increased by 30% with more than 5,000 people consuming more fish.

title_oics: Significant nutrition gains on nearly 150,000 people in Cambodia strengthen the validation of  community-managed rice field fisheries attracting more investments for scaling
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: WorldFish research has shown that well-managed community fish refuges (CFRs) can significantly improve fish productivity of rice field environments, leading to more nutritious fish available for household consumption, contributing to improvements in food security and decreasing malnutrition. WorldFish monitoring in Cambodia shows 149,416 people (51.5% female) consumed more fish at home compared to the previous year, and there has been a 94.3% decrease in proportion of households removing viscera and heads of small fish species, contributing to nutrient increases.

title_oics: The Fisherwomen Community Savings Groups (CSGs) in Bangladesh empower 6,000 poor women by providing visible economic and social benefits while conserving the biodiversity
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Following the successful footprint of ECOFISH related to the Community Saving Group (CSG) activities for fisherwomen, ECOFISH II continued the monitoring of established 148 CSGs in the Meghna River Ecosystem (MRE) area and formed 29 new CSGs with 5,983 active members who saved cumulatively USD 168,170. This approach has led to women empowerment for providing collateral-free soft loan among themselves. In 2020, additional 537 women received soft loans from this savings and reinvested them in different small-scale businesses.

title_oics: Research and application of co-management strategies enhance the contribution to sustainable increase in hilsa production while providing socio-economic resilience for over 34,676 fishers in Bangladesh
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: The co-management interventions implemented by ECOFISH II, contributed to produce 6% extra annual increment of hilsa fish production and improving its size. The project has led improvements in livelihood resilience and poverty reduction of fishing communities in the Bay of Bengal. The ECOFISH II co-management of coastal fisheries resources contributes to reach the UN Sustainable Development Goal 14, SDG 1 and SDG 2. Other 158,095 hectares of biologically significant areas have been restore thanks to improved natural resource management

title_oics: The promotion of integrated farming systems increased rice yields by 18% and nutritious fish for farmers in Myanmar
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: The Naypyitaw agreement established in 2018 encourages integrated agriculture for rice-fish production by allowing up to 15% of a farmer’s rice-field area can be converted into fish holding refuges for integrated rice-fish production systems. Using better management practices for rice, fish and water are shown to increase rice yield, profitability, employment options for women and nutrition for families. Piloting in 2020 suggests that despite a reduction of rice land, farmers are able to increase rice harvest by 18%.

title_oics: Research on hilsa conservation incentives  provides strong evidence to the government of Myanmar in designing a fisheries management mechanism that promotes livelihood diversification and resilience
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Research activities on socio-economics, biology and ecology of hilsa fishery in Myanmar are providing compelling evidence to the Government in reviewing its fiscal reforms strategy to mobilise and tailor additional resources towards a system of incentive-based hilsa fisheries management.Combining incentives with evidence-based regulations should help the government to implement SDGs 14 and 15. Progress is being made towards a good management structure

title_oics: 15,690 km2 marine area under improved fisheries management through the real-time monitoring of fishing activities and catch in Timor-Leste
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: The PeskAAS digital fisheries monitoring system developed with and for the government of Timor-Leste to more effectively gather data on catch and distribution of fishing effort, has been officially launched and adopted by the Government. As such a marine area 15,690 km2 -  representing the national fleet limited to small-scale vessels in territorial waters, is under improved fisheries management through the real-time monitoring of fishing activities and catch, which provides timely data for timely decision making.

title_oics: High oleic groundnut varieties commercialized in India meet the enhanced shelf-life needs of food industry and consumer health benefits.
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: High oleic groundnut varieties are preferred by food processing industry for enhanced shelf-life benefits and has consumer health benefits. The process innovations in breeding and testing pipeline resulted in commercialisation of high oleic cultivars in India in 8-years of time as against the normal 12-15 years. The partnership between the national program in India and ICRISAT, and long-term donor support was critical for the success. ICRISAT has shared the high oleic lines  with nine countries in Africa and Asia.

title_oics: Efficient legume seed systems benefitting more than 22 million smallholder farmers in about 4.4 million hectares in the 15 countries in the semi-arid tropics
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: Tropical Legumes (TL) Project together with precursor and complementary projects facilitated the development of 304 nutrient dense, climate-smart, farmer- and market-preferred varieties and the production of 397,050 t (t) of certified and quality declared seeds (QDS). The seed was planted on about 4.4 million hectares (ha) by more than 22 million smallholder farmers in the 15 target countries and beyond, producing about 4.9 million t of grain worth US$ 2.6 billion.

title_oics: Climbing bean technology that upscaling from Rwanda increases availability of nutrient-dense food among 90,000 families as it conquers bigger share of bean area in Burundi
title_project: Generic Project to Link the AR Data on CGIAR Program Results Dashboard
outcome_impact_statement: By adopting climbing beans from Rwanda, bean national production of Burundi increased by an extra 87852 tons (6). At a per capita consumption of 45 kg per person per year, the additional production feeds 1,952,261 people per year; with 90,000 adopting families, reporting that they had more food available  than before, which enabled them to consume more nutrient dense food even during lean period than they would have if they had not adopted

title_oics: Vietnam reduced additional 1.5MtCO2-eq/year through outscaling low-emission technologies in rice production with IRRI-CCAFS' contributions and increases Agriculture-Nationally Determined Contributions mitigation target by 16MtCO2-eq by 2030.
title_project: GHG mitigation in rice: From evidence-based concepts to adoption at scale
outcome_impact_statement: In its updated Nationally Determined Contributions, Vietnam raised the Agriculture-greenhouse gas mitigation target by 16MtCO2-eq; 100% of Ag-unconditional target will come from rice. With IRRI-CCAFS contributions, climate-smart rice production was introduced to 17,000 extension staff and 75,800 farmers within Vietnam's extension programs; while the Vietnam-Sustainable Agriculture Transformation project almost doubled the low-emission technology adoption area, reaching 163,418ha. Alternate Wetting and Drying and rice straw removal are outscaled in An Giang province. These expansions together saves additional 1.5MtCO20eq/year compared to 2019.

title_oics: Philippine government adopts CCAFS outputs and inputs in reviewing, developing, and implementing climate-smart agriculture-related policies and programs
title_project: [Regional Program Leader] SEA: Regional and National synthesis, engagement and support
outcome_impact_statement: Outputs and recommendations developed by CCAFS were used by key Philippine government agencies (specifically the Department of Agriculture[DA]) in reviewing, developing, and implementing national policies and key programs, including the Rice Competitiveness Enhancement Fund(RCEF). Through RCEF, the Philippine government allotted PhP60B (USD1.2B) for climate-smart rice production, targeting 1.89 million rice farmers in 57 provinces of the country. Since the RCEF implementation in 2020, CCAFS innovations (i.e., Climate-Smart Village, school-on-the air) are being used as platforms for implementing the program's components.

title_oics: Vietnam's rice-producing regions (1.3 M ha) cope with water shortage, drought, and salinity intrusion by applying the CCAFS' Climate-Smart Maps and Adaptation Plans
title_project: [Regional Program Leader] SEA: Regional and National synthesis, engagement and support
scope_comments: Major rice-producing regions in Vietnam, such as Mekong River Delta, Red River Delta and Northern Mountainous Region, and South Central Coast.
outcome_impact_statement: Vietnam's Department of Crop Production (DCP) has been implementing the Climate-Smart Maps and Adaptation Plans (CS-MAP) for the rice production in Mekong River Delta (MRD). To address the salinity intrusion during the Winter-Spring season 2019-2020 and 2020-2021, cropping adjustments guided by CS-MAP were applied in more than 800,000ha and 500,000ha, respectively. CS-MAP has also been applied to other major rice-producing areas of Red River Delta and Northern Midlands (for irrigation management) and South Central Coast (for drought and salinity intrusion).

title_oics: CCAFS impact assessment of national policy engagement in Kenya on uptake of climate-smart agriculture technologies and practices
title_project: RPL EA: Regional and national engagement, synthesis and strategic research
scope_comments: In other countries in EA where CCAFS has been active in supporting policy processes. These include

title_oics: Assessment of adoption and impact of management innovations in agriculture carbon project
title_project: RPL EA: Regional and national engagement, synthesis and strategic research
scope_comments: NA

title_oics: Introduction of vegetable production in smallholder systems: a promising option for livelihood improvement and climate change adaptation
title_project: Policy Support for Climate Resilient, Biodiversity-rich Seed Systems
scope_comments: The pilot experience in Hoima district could very likely be replicated in many other districts of the country if farmers are motivated and if initial technical support can be provided.

title_oics: Rwanda Climate Services for Agriculture: Evaluation of farmers’ awareness, use and impacts
title_project: RPL EA: Regional and national engagement, synthesis and strategic research
scope_comments: Similar programs or programs implementing similar initiatives across scales.

title_oics: Rwanda Climate Services for Agriculture: Farmers willingness to pay for improved climate services
title_project: RPL EA: Regional and national engagement, synthesis and strategic research
scope_comments: NA

title_oics: CCAFS Contributes to the Revision of the Climate Change Strategy and Action Plan for the Southern African Development Community
title_project: [Flagship Leader] FP1: Engagement, synthesis and support
outcome_impact_statement: Through its appointment to the Southern African Development Community (SADC) Secretariat’s climate change expert group, CCAFS contributed directly to the revision of the SADC Climate Change Strategy and Action Plan (2020-2030). CCAFS engaged with a range of experts to assist with thematic expertise and contributions.  Through strategic content input and coordination activities, the Climate Change Strategy was updated and strengthened on aspects of climate-smart agriculture and sustainable land use, as well as on the inclusion of gender and youth considerations.

title_oics: Translating complex climate science into practical agro-climate advisories for 13-15 million smallholder farmers in Ethiopia
title_project: RPL EA: Regional and national engagement, synthesis and strategic research
scope_comments: NA
outcome_impact_statement: Creation of Ethiopia’s digital agro-climate advisory platform, a collaborative partnership between government institutions and CGIAR centers, represents a breakthrough in providing climate-information and timely decision-support tools to smallholder farmers to strengthen adaptive capacity and resilience. Partnership between Ministry of Agriculture and EDACaP team with Ethiopia’s FANA Broadcasting Corporate led to dissemination of agro-climate messages to 13-15 million smallholder farmers across FANA’s 11 regional broadcasting centers in Ethiopia. Information used for planning farming activities for season taking into consideration climate-related risks.

title_oics: CCAFS and partners' three investment outcome pathways are associated with more than USD 3.5 billion Climate Smart Agriculture investments globally
title_project: [Flagship Leader] FP1: Engagement, synthesis and support
outcome_impact_statement: The work of CCAFS and partners over the last 10 years in the research and engagement arenas has influenced the investment decisions of a diverse range of investors globally. This has been achieved via multiple investment-oriented outcome pathways and entry points for influencing public and private sector actors in a wide range of countries. The lessons that are being distilled from these experiences will continue to guide future investment planning for resilient and climate-smart food systems.

title_oics: "Let it rain" game led to 25,312 successful players and new sign up's to iShamba: Farmer information service in Kenya
title_project: Inspire Challenge Winner 2019: Gamifying weather forecasting: “Let it rain” campaign
outcome_impact_statement: The game developed in collaboration between CIAT, the Mediae development communications firm, iShamba (the digital advisory service linked to the popular "Shamba Shape Up" television program) and the game developer Usiku saw 25,312 people play the Let it rain game and subsequently sign up to the iShamba farmer mobile service to receive weekly information on selected crops and livestock, weather and market prices.

title_oics: Sustainable beef certification scheme supported by research on low-emission technologies, monitoring more than 60,000 ha for beef production and forest conservation in Colombia
title_project: Catalyzing farmer innovations and the adoption of promising management and technological options to facilitate the development of low-carbon cattle value chains in Latin America
scope_comments: We are currently in conversation with a second supermarket chain and trust they will adopt GANSO certification scheme by 2021
outcome_impact_statement: Aiming at generating impact in low carbon livestock production, CIAT-CCAFS and Climate Focus created a technical and financial assistance center in Colombia (GANSO). GANSO developed a certification scheme that is now in place for sustainable beef production. The largest retailer in Colombia (Exito) already adopted it and started selling through its channels, facilitating market-based climate action. Consumers pay premium prices for certified-GANSO products and Exito pays a bonus to the farmer for producing beef with environmental, social and animal-management pillars
