title_oics: Eight countries improve MRV for climate change mitigation to better track Nationally Determined Contributions (NDC) mitigation targets (24% of total annual agriculture emissions) for agriculture.
title_project: [Flagship Leader] FP3: Engagement, synthesis and support
scope_comments: MRV approaches and guidance have global application to any countries tracking their emissions.
outcome_impact_statement: Brazil, China, Colombia, Cuba, Ethiopia, Indonesia, Kenya, and Vietnam used CCAFS science and resources to improve national greenhouse gas estimates. Improved MRV enabled countries to set evidence-based mitigation targets in their domestic climate policies and nationally determined contributions (NDCs). Total agricultural emissions from these countries range from 1.4 to 1.9 GtCO2 yr-1 and six of the countries are among the top 20 GHG emitters in the livestock sector. More accurate monitoring supports better tracking and transparency of NDC mitigation targets.

title_oics: COVID-19 and the bovine livestock sector in Colombia: Current and potential developments, impacts and mitigation options
title_project: Catalyzing farmer innovations and the adoption of promising management and technological options to facilitate the development of low-carbon cattle value chains in Latin America

title_oics: CCAFS science informs updated mitigation commitments for livestock in the Nationally Determined Contributions in Ethiopia and Kenya
title_project: RPL EA: Regional and national engagement, synthesis and strategic research
scope_comments: Other countries in Sub-Saharan Africa
outcome_impact_statement: CCAFS, UNIQUE and Ethiopia’s Ministry of Agriculture collaborated to develop new inventory of livestock greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions using Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Tier 2 approach which was used to update Ethiopia’s Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC) commitments for livestock GHG mitigation. CCAFS supported Kenya’s State Department for Livestock, increasing its understanding of livestock GHG mitigation options, leading to prioritization of efficient livestock production in Kenya’s updated NDC. Ethiopia and Kenya submitted updated NDCs to UNFCCC in December 2020.

title_oics: Forty percent of Colombian rice producers cultivating 275,608 hectares adopt improved rice varieties developed by CCAFS/Alliance and Rice Growers’ Federation with Ministry of Agriculture support
title_project: [Regional Program Leader] LAM: Local to National/Regional synthesis, research and engagement
outcome_impact_statement: Since 2013, CCAFS/Alliance Bioversity-CIAT collaborated with the Colombian Ministry of Agriculture and Rice Growers Federation through the AclimateColombia program to increase farmers’ resilience to climate change and climate variability while improving productivity. An ex-post assessment demonstrated that improved rice varieties developed during program implementation were adopted by 40% (6,424) of in total 16,060 rice farmers. 57% (9,154 farmers) used agroclimatic forecasts to manage their crop. Program technical assistance led to an average rice yield increase of 0.6 tons per hectare.

title_oics: World Bank Group interested in adoption of ACE calculator for assessing the projects they sponsor
title_project: Reducing agro-food induced GHG emissions through effective FLW reducing strategies

title_oics: The Seeds Without Borders Agreement in South Asia is easing rice varieties sharing among countries
title_project: IRRI Contribution to RICE Flagship Project 1
scope_comments: This activity was focused on South Asia.
outcome_impact_statement: The Seeds Without Borders (SWB) Agreement facilitates sharing rice varieties across member countries. Through SWB Agreement, member countries can get access to improved varieties of rice, which help to increase productivity, food security and farm income and thereby achieving SDG 1 and 2.

title_oics: Use of PeskAAS (Automated Analytics System), adopted by the government of Timor-Leste, led to improved fisheries policy, strategy, and management
title_project: Inspire Winner Scale Up Runner Up 2019: An integrated data pipeline for small-scale fisheries
outcome_impact_statement: The PeskAAS digital monitoring system directly influenced national fisheries management and policy in Timor-Leste.  The Government of Timor-Leste (GOTL) has adopted the system and fund its use and maintenance at about $150,000/year, hiring 15 enumerators nationwide to gather data.  GOTL is able to provide fisheries statistics to FAO for the first time since 2003, and the system is integrated into the language of relevant articles of the national fisheries decree law. An undergraduate fisheries program has adopted PeskAAS as well.

title_oics: New ARICA 6 variety adapted to iron toxicity in lowlands increases the rive farmers income by USD 120 per hectare for 8,200 farmers
title_project: AfricaRice Contribution to RICE Flagship Project 1
outcome_impact_statement: Iron toxicity is one of the most important abiotic stresses limiting rice production in SSA lowlands and affects up to 60% of the lowland rice area in West and Central Africa. ARICA 6 has shown that it is high-yielding, well adapted to plains and lowlands and very tolerant of iron toxicity. Impact assessment showed that ARICA 6 variety increased rice yield by 330 kg ha-1 and net income by USD 120 ha-1.

title_oics: CGIAR modeling approaches for resource-constrained scenarios: I. Accelerating crop breeding for a changing climate
title_project: CoP Crop Modeling Module 2

title_oics: CGIAR modeling approaches for resource-constrained scenarios: II. Models for analyzing socioeconomic factors to improve policy recommendations
title_project: CoP Crop Modeling Module 2

title_oics: Use of ASI thresher helps 45,600 rice farmers to accees more credit to expand and intensify rice production in Senegal
title_project: AfricaRice Contribution to RICE Flagship Project 1
scope_comments: Senegal, Nigeria, Benin, Uganda
outcome_impact_statement: We examine whether the adoption of the ASI thresher technology by rice farmers in the Senegal River Valley increases their access to credit and their creditworthiness through various pathways. The results show that ASI rice thresher adopters borrowed more money (between USD 388 and 864) per season in comparison to their neighbours who had not adopted the ASI thresher.

title_oics: Rural transformation and the future of rice-based food systems
title_project: AfricaRice Contribution to RICE Flagship Project 1

title_oics: AfricaRice innovations contribute to the rice production and value chain upgrading with 10,890 producers in West Africa benefited from contract farming
title_project: AfricaRice Contribution to RICE Flagship Project 1
outcome_impact_statement: We assess the state of rice value chain upgrading in West Africa by reviewing evidence on rice millers’ investment in semi-industrial and industrial milling technologies, contract farming and vertical integration during 2009–2019. We found that upgrading is more dynamic in countries with high production and import bills. In 2019, there were 57 industrial mills with an aggregate capacity of 315 tons/hour. We found contract farming in eight countries, involving 10,890 producers, and vertical coordination in five countries, covering 29,240 ha.

title_oics: Understanding CCAFS’ influence in motivating actors to tackle climate change
title_project: [Flagship Leader] FP2: Engagement, synthesis and support

title_oics: New plant types possessing as many as 10 QTLs identified after profiling with 30 trait-based SNPs
title_project: AfricaRice contribution to flagship project 5

title_oics: Eight thousand Uzbekistan farmers cultivating 360,000 hectares are using water-accounting tools to improve water distribution making further expansion a national priority for 2020-2030
title_project: Water and irrigation in Central Asia
outcome_impact_statement: An innovative water-measurement and accounting tool developed and tested by WLE/IWMI and partners, "smart sticks", have proven successful in improving water accounting in Uzbekistan irrigation associations. They enable associations to automatically record how much water has been delivered to which farmers. This accurate, transparent and easy-to-use tool resolves conflicts over water distribution and incentivizes farmers to pay irrigation fees. As a result, the technology was included among priority investments in the Agricultural Development Strategy of Uzbekistan for 2020-2030.

title_oics: Rwanda Climate Services for Agriculture project demonstrates significant productivity, income, food security and women’s empowerment benefits for more than 110,000 participating farmers
title_project: Climate Services for Agriculture: Empowering Farmers to Manage Risk and Adapt to a Changing Climate in Rwanda
outcome_impact_statement: Evaluation shows that the 111,835 farmers, across all 30 districts, who participated in Rwanda Climate Services for Agriculture (RCSA) communication and capacity development interventions were more likely to act on weather and climate information; experienced an average 24% increase in the value of crop production and 30% increase in income from crops; and perceived improvements in food security, investment in farming, coping capacity, and confidence as farmers.  Project interventions increased women’s participation in household decision-making and standing in their communities.

title_oics: Picture-based crop monitoring adopted by six institutions (private-sector insurance companies and associated partners) to improve agricultural insurance and financing services in India, Kenya and Ethiopia
title_project: 3.2.4 Innovative Risk Management Tools for the Poor
outcome_impact_statement: Picture-Based Insurance provides affordable high-quality crop insurance by using smartphone images of smallholders’ crops. PIM research has led to large-scale testing and adoption of picture-based crop monitoring by private-sector insurance companies and associated partners HDFC ERGO General Insurance (India), Dvara E-Registry (India), Government of India, ACRE Africa (Kenya), R4 Rural Resilience Initiative (Ethiopia) and Centre for Agriculture and Bioscience International (CABI) (India, Kenya), creating opportunities to strengthen crop insurance, financing and agro-advisories for millions of farmers.

title_oics: Accessing and using seasonal forecasts through digital platforms has improved the livelihood of 363,000 men and 137,000 women farmers and fisherfolks in across Senegal.
title_project: [Regional Program Leader] WA: Regional/National synthesis, engagement and support
outcome_impact_statement: Impact evaluation revealed that the use of seasonal forecast by 363,000 men and 137,000 women farmers increased major crops' productivity and farm profitability in Senegal. Millet and rice yields increased by 22% and 19% respectively from using seasonal forecast information in farm management decisions. Aggregate farm profits increased income by 15% on average with 23% increase among men and 5% among women that used seasonal forecasts, implying differential incremental incomes of $56 and $11 for men and women respectively.

title_oics: The effects of CGIAR work on Smart-Valleys on soil moisture and rice yield in four inland valleys assessed
title_project: Climate-smart rice technologies to enhance resilience of smallholder rice farmers in Burkina Faso

title_oics: Picture-based crop monitoring is adopted in India, Ethiopia and Kenya by 6 public and private institutions to advance their agricultural insurance and finance services
title_project: Building a Global Agricultural Insurance Community of Practice: From Evidence to Scale and Sustainability
outcome_impact_statement: Picture-Based Insurance provides affordable high-quality crop insurance by using smartphone images of smallholders’ crops for settlement of claims. PIM research led to large-scale testing and adoption of picture-based crop monitoring by private entities as HDFC ERGO General Insurance (India), Dvara E-Registry (India), the Government of India, ACRE Africa (Kenya), public entity R4 Rural Resilience Initiative (Ethiopia) and the Centre for Agriculture and Bioscience International (CABI) (India, Kenya), creating opportunities to strengthen crop insurance, financing and agro-advisories for millions of farmers.

title_oics: Picture-based crop monitoring is adopted by six institutions to improve their agricultural insurance and financing services
title_project: Inspire Scale-Up Winner 2018: Seeing Is Believing
outcome_impact_statement:
Picture-Based Insurance provides affordable high-quality crop insurance by using smartphone images
of smallholders’ crops for settlement of claims. The research led to adoption of picture-based crop monitoring by private companies HDFC ERGO General Insurance (India), Dvara E-Registry (India), and ACRE Africa (Kenya); government of India, and development organizaions including the R4 Rural Resilience Initiative (Ethiopia) and the Centre for Agriculture and Bioscience International (CABI) (India, Kenya), creating opportunities to strengthen crop insurance, financing and agro-advisories for millions of farmers.

title_oics: Can restoration of commons foster resilience?  Comparing COVID-19 induced livelihood impacts and coping strategies among villages targeted by a largescale common land restoration initiative
title_project: Piloting and scaling an integrated framework and methods for monitoring, evaluating, and enhancing the effectiveness of large-scale land restoration initiatives (PIM-WLE-FTA initiative)
scope_comments: n/a

title_oics: Rwanda government adopts and integrates animal source foods consumption communication materials into the national maternal and child nutrition curriculum to improve nutrition outcomes
title_project: Product Line 5.3.1: Menu of approaches for nutrition-sensitive livestock-related interventions to improve availability, affordability, access and utilization of animal-source foods
scope_comments: N/A
outcome_impact_statement: IILRI and its partners have implemented a social and behavior change communication intervention on animal source foods consumption, particularly the drinking of milk among Girinka households in Rwanda. This was implemented through a Feed the Future Innovations Labs for Livestock Systems (LSIL) research project. In 2020 the national counselling cards were updated to include animal source foods consumption messages, which have been validated through the National Child Development Agency and are now being used nationally by community health workers.

title_oics: Integrating Conventional and Participatory Crop Improvement for Smallholder Agriculture Using the Seeds for Needs Approach: A Review
title_project: Using biodiversity, including genetic diversity, for land restoration

title_oics: Early sowing of heat-tolerant wheat, new machinery and agronomic management enable 1.1M farmers in South Asia: Greater resilience, productivity and climate change adaptation
title_project: Coordination of CoA 4.3
scope_comments: South Asia
outcome_impact_statement: High-yielding wheat varieties with tolerance to heat stress, in combination with systemic innovations for climate change adaptation, enabled farmers in the Eastern and Western Indo-Gangetic Plains (IGP) to sow earlier and grow their income, while reducing their environmental footprint by avoiding burning crop residue and reducing irrigation.  0.3 million farmers in Western IGP and 0.8 million in Eastern IGP practiced the innovations, achieving extra yields with less irrigation, and earning an additional income of ~US$ 200/ha.

title_oics: WHEAT and MAIZE science, partnerships, outreach lead to policies for conservation agriculture and precision nutrient management in South Asia, mitigating climate change, increasing smallholder income
title_project: Coordination of CoA 4.3
outcome_impact_statement: Continued WHEAT and MAIZE efforts in scientific evidence, innovative partnerships and enhanced capacity led to policy changes for large-scale adoption of low-emission, risk-mitigating practices in smallholder wheat systems in South Asia. Adoption of conservation agriculture in 2 million hectares and precision nutrient management in 20 million hectares would potentially benefit around 14 million smallholders, producing around 14 million tons of extra grain, and earning US$ 1.3 billion in additional revenue, while reducing ~3.4 million tons of CO2e each year.

title_oics: Common bean improvement research helps to reduce poverty for 2.5 million families in Ethiopia
title_project: 4. Going to scale with production technology: seed and crop management
outcome_impact_statement: Recent Alliance-led research has significantly impacted Ethiopia’s bean sector including breeding, seed systems, varieties grown, and farmers’ welfare. The research has released over 60 varieties adapted to all agro-ecological zones over time. Generally, adoption of improved varieties has benefited close to 2.5 million farming families, enabling them to enjoy extra consumption spending on food and non-food items worth USD 119 (PPP) per person per year, and by USD 217 (PPP) for those families that combined varieties with fertilizers.

title_oics: Does farm structure affect rural household incomes in Tanzania?
title_project: RENEWAL: Taking Maize Agronomy to Scale in Africa (TAMASA)
scope_comments: with relevance to Eastern and Southern Africa

title_oics: Use of the Multistakeholder Dialogue Platform approach for effective participation of local communities in interventions for biodiversity conservation and enhanced livelihoods across the Kenya-Somalia border
title_project: 5.2.1 Governing Shared Landscapes
outcome_impact_statement: PIM researchers developed a toolkit to facilitate and strengthen a Multistakeholder Dialogue Platform to guide design and implementation of the Intergovernmental Authority for Development of the Horn of Africa’s cross border Biodiversity Management Programme in Kenya-Somalia, delivering biodiversity and livelihood benefits to local communities and benefitting roughly 3,000 farmers.

title_oics: Nationwide scaling out and international adoption of "Agua de Honduras": A platform developed by WLE/Alliance to improve water management investment decisions
title_project: Implementation of the "Agua de Honduras" Platform in Development Region 13 and Implementation of a web tool for the identification of sites with rainwater harvest potential in Central America
scope_comments: Initially developed and used in Honduras, the tool is now being scaled out in Belize, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Ethiopia, Grenada, Guatemala, Kenya, Nicaragua, Panama and Rwanda.
outcome_impact_statement: Initially developed by WLE/CIAT and partners, the ?Agua de Honduras? platform is being scaled out from western Honduras to additional regions. Further, its award-winning tool, AGRI (AGua para RIego), has attracted the attention of other international agencies: they are supporting its implementation in Central America, Ethiopia, Grenada, Kenya and Rwanda. These regions? decision makers can now use these novel tools to better manage their water resources and investments.

title_oics: WLE/IWMI business models research at the sanitation-agriculture interface used in pan-Indian training program which will target over 5,000 officials in the next two years
title_project: RUL Flagship Funds
outcome_impact_statement: WLE/IWMI’s analysis of 15 business models for fecal sludge management, including its treatment for energy or nutrient recovery in agriculture, was used by the Indian Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) Institute to develop capacity building modules. In 2021 and 2022, in collaboration with sector ministries across India, these will be used to train 2,860 government officials, 500 NGO professionals, 60 entrepreneurs, 1,200 sanitation workers, 320 treatment plant operators, and 240 graduates and postgraduates working in the WASH sector.

title_oics: WLE/Alliance-supported data sharing and big data applications being rolled out in Ethiopia to encourage the government's efforts to transform agriculture
title_project: Promoting multifunctional landscapes
scope_comments: The effort is being scaled in other countries such as Rwanda and India.
outcome_impact_statement: A collaborative effort by WLE/Alliance, GIZ-Ethiopia and partners to institutionalize data sharing has led the Ethiopian Ministry of Agriculture to adopt the concept. Partners undertook many activities: creation of a digital web portal, data collation, standardization guidelines and big data analysis. They are now developing a site-specific fertilizer recommendation tool. This has led to better-targeted recommendations and a paradigm shift in the research and development discourse as well as further funding and scaling of the framework to other countries.

title_oics: New approach to water users’ associations in pump-based irrigation schemes in Myanmar results in equitable water allocation and boosts production
title_project: Revitalising irrigation
outcome_impact_statement: Funded through the Livelihoods and Food Security Fund (LIFT) from December 2016 to mid-2019, WLE/IWMI developed a novel approach to establishing water users? associations (WUAs) in pump-based irrigation schemes in Myanmar. This was accompanied by the introduction of new crop varieties and high-quality pulse and rice seeds by Welthungerhilfe and ICRISAT. Despite a drought, farmers reported 1.5 years after LIFT ended that their WUA had enabled them to double the irrigated area and increase crop production.

title_oics: WLE/IWMI research influenced Ethiopian water sector policy reform to recognize multiple water values and other up-to-date options, benefitting irrigators, domestic and industrial users, and environment
title_project: Resilience and sustainability through small scale irrigation intensification
outcome_impact_statement: The Ethiopian Government has initiated a process of water policy reform. WLE/IWMI was approached by the Ministries of Agriculture and of Water, Irrigation, and Electricity to contribute to the review. Drawing from its research, WLE/IWMI brought new ideas to the policy reform table. These ideas include the concept of multiple water values; payment for ecosystem services; irrigation cost recovery, and irrigation performance benchmarking. These options have been incorporated in the draft policy document and will strengthen climate change adaptation.

title_oics: Use of New Extensionist Kit and Global Good Practice Notes on extension in curricula of 63 agricultural universities in India and one South African university
title_project: 1.2.2 Agricultural Extension and Advisory Services
outcome_impact_statement: The New Extensionist Learning Kit, a set of training modules designed to improve functional skills of agricultural extension agents, and a collection of standardized, easy to understand, extension materials called “Global Good Practice notes”, both produced with support from PIM between 2014 and 2020, were incorporated into the Indian national extension curriculum (to be used by 63 universities) and into a university’s curriculum in South Africa.

title_oics: The "Native Basket" brand is launched in India to safeguard and promote heirloom native crops
outcome_impact_statement: ‘Native Basket’ is a marketing brand launched in October 2020—under the UNEP-GEF/CGIAR/ICAR-funded project initiated in January 2017—as part of a holistic strategy to safeguard and promote Assam region’s many precious native heirloom crop varieties. Twenty-six heirloom rice varieties, and nine processed products deriving from them, have been selected based on field trials and seed multiplication, farmers’ and consumers’ preferences, in-depth market demand research/analysis, and the nutritional profiling of >60 landraces of native rice undertaken during 2018, 2019 and 2020.

title_oics: An Alliance study informed the action plan to implement a zero-deforestation and a peacebuilding initiative in Colombia
outcome_impact_statement: An Alliance study supported by the Sustainable Land Use Project, which Germany’s International Climate Initiative funds, was acknowledged for its contribution to developing the action plan of the Cocoa, Forests & Peace Initiative in Colombia. The Alliance is now a signatory to the Initiative. It is poised to generate bigger outcomes from its engagement with the Colombian cocoa sector stakeholders and contributions to prioritizing future research needs.

title_oics: WLE/IWMI research findings on water and energy use in lift irrigated areas have impacted water policies in Uzbekistan, potentially applicable to over two million hectares
title_project: Water and irrigation in Central Asia
outcome_impact_statement: WLE/IWMI research findings demonstrated that substantial water and energy savings could be achieved by adopting more efficient irrigation technologies in the lift irrigated areas of Uzbekistan. Researchers engaged with decision makers and recommended that the government shift subsidies from energy to water saving technologies. This recommendation has been adopted in a state program on water saving technologies covering 450,000 hectares in 2021.

title_oics: WLE/Alliance leadership of a multi-stakeholder platform secretariat prompted dairy giants to join the zero-deforestation movement in Colombia
title_project: Restoration of deforested/degraded areas in Colombia, Peru, Haiti and El Salvador
outcome_impact_statement: The Alliance was asked to lead the multi-stakeholder platform technical Secretariat for Colombia’s zero-deforestation dairy value chain agreement. Alliance staff and partners went on an outreach blitz to encourage the sector’s big players to sign the agreement. With active engagement and support provided by the Secretariat, Alpina, a large corporation, and Asoleche, the national association of milk processors, signed the agreement within a year.

title_oics: First nationally representative, large-scale wheat DNA fingerprinting study
title_project: Building Adoption/Impact and Learning portfolio in WHEAT AFS, including meta-analyses, syntheses, gap analysis, new methods and inter-CRP collaboration

title_oics: Lessons Learnt from the Wheat Seed Scaling Project 2015-2019
title_project: Build up rust screening capacity at Debre Zeit for durum wheat

title_oics: Prospects of South Asian smallholder production systems to adapt to climatic variability, minimizing negative impacts of climate change on food systems
title_project: Planning and coordination of FP/CoA/WP via W-MC, inter-CRP collaboration, maintain/new partnerships
scope_comments: Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka

title_oics: Adoption of the "How are we doing?" tool by the Peruvian Service for Natural Protected Areas to enable more equitable co-management of 76 protected areas
title_project: 5.2.1 Governing Shared Landscapes
outcome_impact_statement: With PIM/FTA support, CIFOR collaborated with multi-stakeholder fora in Peru and Indonesia to develop a tool that allows participants to monitor and reflect on the processes and progress of their fora so that more equitable processes and outcomes may emerge. Partnering with Peru’s Service for Natural Protected Areas, CIFOR adapted this tool for annual implementation by the multi-stakeholder Management Committees of 76 protected areas covering 15% of Peru’s territory.

title_oics: Crop residue burning, air pollution and mitigation evidence for diﬀerent tillage practices in Northwest India
title_project: Planning and coordination of FP/CoA/WP via W-MC, inter-CRP collaboration, maintain/new partnerships

title_oics: Understand low level of adoption of new durum wheat cultivars in Morocco (learning generated about adoption dynamics)
title_project: ICARDA Flagship 1 project

title_oics: Conservation agriculture-based wheat production system to minimize losses due to climate risks: adoption dynamics learning and benefits evidence, including climate change.)
title_project: USAID- Cereal Systems for South Asia (CSISA)- Phase III

title_oics: Designing profitable, resource use efficient, environmentally sound cereal based systems for the Western Indo-Gangetic plains
title_project: USAID- Cereal Systems for South Asia (CSISA)- Phase III

title_oics: Assessing technological change in Global South agri-food systems: Meta-analysis of adoption-impact studies in wheat systems
title_project: Building Adoption/Impact and Learning portfolio in WHEAT AFS, including meta-analyses, syntheses, gap analysis, new methods and inter-CRP collaboration

title_oics: Estimating adoption and impacts of farm/agronomic practices in developing countries using satellite data
title_project: Building Adoption/Impact and Learning portfolio in WHEAT AFS, including meta-analyses, syntheses, gap analysis, new methods and inter-CRP collaboration

title_oics: Meta-analysis of small-scale producers' adoption of climate-resilient crops in the Global South in the last 30 years
title_project: Building Adoption/Impact and Learning portfolio in WHEAT AFS, including meta-analyses, syntheses, gap analysis, new methods and inter-CRP collaboration

title_oics: The Diversity for Restoration Tool is perceived as pivotal for strengthening decision-making on native tree species and seed sources among restoration stakeholders in Latin America
title_project: 1.  Restoration (forest and landscape restoration)
outcome_impact_statement:
Diversity for Restoration (D4R) is a decision support tool that helps in species selection and seed sourcing for restoration using local site conditions and user-determined restoration objectives.
D4R was first piloted for the Colombian tropical dry forest, but recently expanded to similar ecosystems in Peru, Ecuador and Burkina Faso, and soon Cameroon. Users of the tool report it is strengthening the seed selection decision-making process and is increasing awareness, knowledge transfer and data management among key stakeholders.

title_oics: Conservation Agriculture-based practices: Major potential to improve economic, biophysical viability and sustainability of MENA region dryland agriculture
title_project: (4.2) Application of conservation agriculture in WANA, water use efficiency in diversified cropping systems, trade off models for crop biomass

title_oics: Review of Nepal's Agricultural Mechanization Promotion Policy 2014 (AMPP)
title_project: SRA Roadmaps - Building Provincial Capacity for Sustainable Agricultural Mechanisation in Nepal

title_oics: Gender-sensitive agricultural mechanization policy and programs in Nepal
title_project: SRA Roadmaps - Building Provincial Capacity for Sustainable Agricultural Mechanisation in Nepal

title_oics: International Wheat Yield Partnership (IWYP) Hub at CIMMYT under WHEAT FP2: A good example of CGIAR/non-CGIAR cross-project learning and translational research
title_project: IWYP Hub
scope_comments: https://www.dropbox.com/home/Marlo?preview=Annual+Report+Format+IWYP+Hub.docx

title_oics: Long term (10–12 years) maize-based Conservation Agriculture's impact on soil hydraulic conductivity & water retention (Malawi)
title_project: Africa RISING: Sustainable intensification of low-input farming systems

title_oics: Bringing together separate disciplinary approaches to impact assessment (Conservation Agriculture in Malawi)
title_project: Africa RISING: Sustainable intensification of low-input farming systems

title_oics: Morocco’s seed system makes progress, but some challenges still remain
title_project: Informing R4D strategies through foresight and targeting

title_oics: Recommendations for policy action to the Secretary of Agriculture and Ministry agencies in Bangladesh, and policy advice to decision makers in India, Mexico and Nigeria
title_project: USAID-CSISA-COVID Response project- Enabling effective COVID-19 crisis response in Nepal through appropriate agricultural machinery, resilience enhancing irrigation and entrepreneurship
scope_comments: South Asia (Bangladesh and India), Central America (Mexico) and Sub-Saharan Africa (Nigeria).
outcome_impact_statement: WHEAT and MAIZE scientists, as part of a multi-Center + international partners (FAO) initiative in Bangladesh, provided recommendations for policy action to the Secretary of Agriculture and Ministry line agencies. This has positioned the CGIAR in Bangladesh as a "go-to" for advice to Government on COVID response. With other partners, WHEAT and MAIZE scientists provided ex ante, foresight and prioritisation advice to decision-makers in India, Mexico and Nigeria, informing policy action.

title_oics: WHEAT/ICARDA analysis and outreach enables government policies that developed the Moroccan national seed sector, adding 300 new seed businesses
title_project: Informing R4D strategies through foresight and targeting
outcome_impact_statement: The 2019 publication of the results of a milestone WHEAT/ICARDA-led 2013 seed sector survey -- coupled with high-level workshops, meetings and discussions with stakeholders --helped shift the political vision in Morocco, leading to several major changes introduced as part of the Green Morocco Plan that have revamped seed business in the country, including the establishment of 300 new seed businesses.

title_oics: Heat and Drought Wheat Improvement Consortium (HEDWIC) at CIMMYT progress report
title_project: 'HeDWIC' initiative to address wheat production in LDCs under global warming during the next 3 decades

title_oics: Improved drought tolerant maize improved farmer yields and livelihoods benefiting 5.4 million households in eastern, western & southern Africa (DTMA, STMA)
title_project: Stress Tolerant Maize for Africa (STMA)- CIMMYT Component
outcome_impact_statement: The Drought Tolerant Maize for Africa (DTMA) and Stress Tolerant Maize for Africa (STMA) projects delivered improved drought- and stress-tolerant maize varieties to smallholder farmers. 200+ drought-tolerant (DT) maize hybrids and open-pollinated varieties (OPV) were released throughout DTMA?s lifetime, benefiting 5.4 million households. Under STMA (ended March 2020), MAIZE and partner scientists deployed over 100 stress-tolerant improved maize varieties, thanks to seed company partners providing 110,000 tons certified seed (2019). Eight million+ households planted them on 5 million hectares (2020).

title_oics: MAIZE and partner scientists  investigated the carbon sequestration potential of conservation agriculture (CA)
title_project: Africa RISING: Sustainable intensification of low-input farming systems
scope_comments: analysis in Harare, central Zimbabwe but analysis for global outreach.

title_oics: Adoption-impact studies in maize  agri-food systems in the Global South
title_project: Enhancing the impact of MAIZE AFS: Planning and coordination of FP/CoA/WP via W-MC, inter-CRP collaboration, maintain/new partnerships
scope_comments: Global South

title_oics: A scoping review of adoption of climate-resilient crops by small-scale producers in low- and middle-income countries
title_project: Enhancing the impact of MAIZE AFS: Planning and coordination of FP/CoA/WP via W-MC, inter-CRP collaboration, maintain/new partnerships
scope_comments: lower- and middle-income countries  that have experienced climate-related impacts

title_oics: Farmer adoption of sustainable intensification agriculture (SIA) technologies in maize systems of the Global South: A review
title_project: Enhancing the impact of MAIZE AFS : Support, monitoring and reporting on FP/CoA/WP progress and deliverables
scope_comments: Global South

title_oics: A4NH, MAIZE and partner scientists examined potential public/private sector-driven interventions in Malawi
title_project: Building Market/Value Chain portfolio in MAIZE AFS, including syntheses, gap analysis, new methods and inter-CRP collaboration
scope_comments: Diagnostic to support Malawi

title_oics: At least six private sector partners use WLE/A4NH/Alliance’s Agrobiodiversity Index products to guide more holistic decision-making
title_project: Sustainable food systems through managing diversity (SustainableFoods)
outcome_impact_statement: The Agrobiodiversity Index was developed by the Alliance of Bioversity International and CIAT with support from WLE, A4NH and partners. Its adoption has contributed to changes in behaviour and discourse by at least six private sector partners. They are increasingly including agrobiodiversity dimensions in their decision-making for more sustainable consumption, production and conservation along the food chain. The process of co-developing applications has broadened their usability and actionability.

title_oics: Biofortified crops have high potential to improve child nutrition in Ethiopia (Oromia).
title_project: Breeding and deploying nutritionally enriched maize germplasm (QPM and high Zn)
scope_comments: randomised trial in Ethiopia

title_oics: Intensification of maize production using improved seed and chemical fertilizer among smallholders in Ethiopia.
title_project: CoA coordination - Support W3/bilateral projects through systems approaches for improved targeting of technologies

title_oics: farmer adoption dynamics learning: African smallholder farmers who have expressed interest in Conservation Agriculture (CA) have generally not progressed to implementation on their farms
title_project: Enhancing the impact of MAIZE AFS : Support, monitoring and reporting on FP/CoA/WP progress and deliverables
scope_comments: South-Eastern Africa

title_oics: Economic analysis of the impacts of fall armyworm (FAW) in Ethiopia
title_project: Coordinating and implementing IPM R4D against Fall Armyworm (FAW) in Africa and Asia, and implementing MLN management in Africa and LatAm
scope_comments: Southern Ethiopia

title_oics: Usefulness of breeder-friendly phenotyping approaches and methods at different stages of the breeding cycle
title_project: 'HeDWIC' initiative to address wheat production in LDCs under global warming during the next 3 decades

title_oics: Review of model-based approaches for crop breeding activities under changing climate
title_project: 'HeDWIC' initiative to address wheat production in LDCs under global warming during the next 3 decades

title_oics: Three WHEAT/CIMMYT elite lines released by Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR) as varieties for North West India's smallholder farmers in record time
title_project: Grain yield, yellow rust and spot blotch phenotyping in South Asia
outcome_impact_statement: Phenotyping data for grain yield, heat tolerance, resistance to yellow rust and spot blotch, to support ICAR-IIWBR (Indian Council of Agricultural Research-Indian Institute of Wheat and Barley Research), the national partner, led to multi-trait improvements (pest and disease resistance, early and terminal heat) that ICAR-IWWBR could turn into varieties released and available to farmers in record time.

title_oics: Pakistan: Speeding up the national trials and variety release process for wheat
title_project: Wheat Productivity Enhancement Project (WPEP) in Pakistan

title_oics: Methodology development for innovation processes cross-program (for Crop Country Initiatives)
title_project: Enhancing the impact of MAIZE AFS: Planning and coordination of FP/CoA/WP via W-MC, inter-CRP collaboration, maintain/new partnerships

title_oics: CGIAR Centers' rapid assessment of food and nutrition security in the context of COVID-19 guides Bangladesh Government action
title_project: Building foresight portfolio for MAIZE AFS, including synthesis, gap analysis and new studies, as input in conducting priority setting for MAIZE AFS
outcome_impact_statement: FAO, IFAD and CGIAR centers led CIMMYT did a quantitative assessment of the impacts of COVID19 in Bangladesh. WHEAT and MAIZE scientists, as part of a multi-Center and international partners (FAO) initiative in Bangladesh, provided recommendations for policy action to the Secretary of Agriculture and Ministry line agencies. This has positioned the CGIAR in Bangladesh as a "go-to" for advice to Government on COVID response.

title_oics: Development of an organizational culture of continuous improvement process across CGIAR breeding programs to support operational excellence
title_project: Module 4 Phenotyping tools and services
scope_comments: Adopting lean methodologies at CGIAR breeding programs has a great potential. The project started in IRRI headquarter in Philippines but will be cascade to other regions.
outcome_impact_statement:
To meet funders/end-users needs, CGIAR breeding programs are modernizing their breeding operations. This doesn't mean a change here/there, but a culture of continuous improvement. By adopting LEAN methodologies (LM) IRRI has been engaging the operational team supporting the modernization process.
LM were established to support operational teams defining their processes adding value to clients' needs. Adopting LM allows breeding teams to better structure processes, reducing redundancies/errors, eliminating waste and bringing effective delivery needs emphasising teamwork within the process.

title_oics: Contributions to national-level policy discourse on response to economic impacts of COVID-19 in Ghana, Malawi, Tunisia and Indonesia
title_project: 2.1.4 Rural-Urban Linkages and Agri-Food System Employment
outcome_impact_statement: In Ghana, Indonesia, Malawi and Tunisia, IFPRI researchers’ work on the economic impacts of COVID-19 based on PIM modeling tools was presented to high-level policy makers and significantly helped shape national-level policy discourse.

title_oics: Sources of resistance to wheat blast and its underlying mechnisim identified, resistant gene(s) introgressed and resistant varieties released in Bangladesh, India and Nepal
title_project: Evaluate wheat lines for resistance to wheat blast in Bolivia and in Bangladesh
outcome_impact_statement: Wheat blast has spread across continents, now present in South America (Brazil, Paraguay, Argentina, Bolivia), Asia (Bangladesh) and Africa (Zambia). Researchers have identified sources of resistance and the underlying resistance mechanism; also introgressed new resistant gene(s) to develop durable resistant varieties. Resistant varieties have been released in Bangladesh, Nepal and India; seed multiplication and dissemination is in progress. The pathogen’s population is clonal in Bangladesh with sensitivity to fungicides, and studies in Zambia about this aspect have just started.

title_oics: Significant genetic gains in grain yield delivered by breeding research: A constant flow of high-yielding, disease-resistant germplasm provided to National Agricultural Research System partners
title_project: Delivering Genetic Gains in Wheat (DGGW)
scope_comments: breeding program elite lines (different trials and nurseries) reach collaborators in 60+ countries every year.
outcome_impact_statement: The CGIAR Research Program on Wheat (WHEAT) bread wheat breeding program at CIMMYT delivered significant genetic gains to National Agricultural Research System (NARS) partners by developing high-yielding, disease-resistant wheat germplasm. Analysis of historical data showed grain yield gains of 46.6 (irrigated), 57.7 (drought), 65.1 (high rainfall) kg/ha/yea, or 0.5-1% p.a. On-station trials of selected varieties/germplasm delivered similar estimates. These genetic gains in grain yield impact an estimated 61 million hectares of the 215 million hectares of the global wheat area.

title_oics: Adoption and Scaling Interventions are progressively guided by gender-responsive research methods across CGIAR CRPs, including WHEAT
title_project: Building Gender and Social Inclusion portfolio in WHEAT AFS, including strategic gender research and inter-CRP collaboration
outcome_impact_statement: Since 2018, researchers and colleagues from within and outside of CGIAR centers have applied gender-responsive research methods in an attempt to unravel the complex social landscapes of different agricultural settings around the world. In doing so, scientists have assessed the dynamics of gender norms, power relations, labor-use, and processes for decision-making in access to and control of resources. These assessments guide research on how social dynamics influence decisions in adoption of climate-smart, energy-saving and cost-effective agricultural technologies.

title_oics: MAIZE, RICE, PIM, WHEAT joint foresight: An assessment on how cereal-based food security systems evolved due to rural transformations
title_project: Building foresight portfolio for WHEAT AFS, including synthesis, gap analysis and new studies, as input in conducting priority setting for WHEAT AFS

title_oics: CCAFS’ influence and reach in motivating actors globally to tackle climate change reaching 60 million people
title_project: [Flagship Leader] FP2: Engagement, synthesis and support
outcome_impact_statement: CCAFS’ science, engagement with strategic partners and capacity strengthening approach has globally i) shifted the debate on climate adaptation among strategic partners, with the program’s ideas having reached nearly 60 million people, ii) inspired positive change in government policy, with nearly 100 policy wins in just the two years up to 2019, iii)  built a global community for climate adaption within a network of more than 60 thousand entities and iv) sparked public interest in CSA.

title_oics: Gender norms, agency, power relations research developed by MAIZE and WHEAT guides other CGIAR and partner researchers impact pathway and scaling interventions
title_project: Building Gender, Youth and Social Inclusion portfolio in MAIZE AFS, including strategic gender research and inter-CRP collaboration
outcome_impact_statement: Since 2018, researchers and colleagues from within and outside of CGIAR centers have applied gender-responsive research methods in an attempt to unravel the complex social landscapes of different agricultural settings around the world. They assessed the dynamics of gender norms, power relations, labor-use, and processes for decision-making in access to and control of resources. These assessments guide own and other CGIAR and partner research on how social dynamics influence decisions in adoption of climate-smart, energy-saving and cost-effective agricultural technologies.

title_oics: Building on PIM COVID-19 research, PIM modeling tools are used to inform ranking of policy investments and identification of priority value chains in Nigeria
title_project: 2.4.2 Support to Nigeria Policies
outcome_impact_statement: PIM researchers conducted an analysis of COVID-19 impacts on Nigeria’s food systems. The information-gathering process, dissemination of initial findings and discussions with stakeholders led to a demand from the Government to use PIM tools to inform planning for Nigeria’s Medium-Term National Development Policy for target years 2025, 2030, and 2050 and for the Nigeria Agenda 2050.

title_oics: Cross-region/project learning from  appropriate-scale mechanization projects: Rural labour dynamics, access and scaling approaches are key issues
title_project: Mechanization of wheat based systems in Sub-Saharan Africa
outcome_impact_statement: MAIZE/WHEAT and partners developed, refined and sustained appropriate-scale mechanization solutions, linked to climate-smart practices (e.g. zero-till, rotation). R4D focused on mitigating labour shortages and building capacity for delivery and support systems. Research revealed a much higher demand for mechanization than previous studies had shown, indicating access is the problem, not demand or affordability. MAIZE/WHEAT projects in Africa, South Asia (on 2 million ha) and Latin America confirmed improved livelihoods and income (opportunity) effects. Constraints to scaling differ, but remain significant.

title_oics: Smallholder farmers use conservation agriculture-based technologies and sustainable intensification practices adapted to climate change on 627,000 ha in southern Africa
title_project: Sustainable Intensification of Smallholder Farming Systems (SIFAZ) in Zambia
outcome_impact_statement: Long-term (2004-2020) Conservation Agriculture (CA) systems research in Malawi, Zambia and Zimbabwe has generated scientific evidence on productivity, profitability, environmental, social and human impacts. This is used in all target countries to inform policies towards more climate-smart agriculture adaptation interventions. Farmer adoption reached >627,000 ha, with yield benefits of 30-50% (up to 140%) under drought. Due to greater water-use efficiency, applying the principles of CA is effective in reducing climate risks thus reducing the vulnerability of farming communities.

title_oics: Farmers plant Heat Tolerant Maize varieties to improve their food security and livelihood in climate-vulnerable areas of South Asia, on over 20,000 ha
title_project: Heat Tolerant Maize for Asia (HTMA) Phase II
outcome_impact_statement: Growing heat-tolerant maize can reduce yield losses due to climate change by up to 36% (rainfed) and 93% (irrigated). Heat Tolerant Maize for Asia (HTMA, 2013-17) helped smallholder farmers in climate-vulnerable ecologies to secure their food security and livelihoods, ensured technologies' equal access to women farmers and incorporated gender-preferred nutrition traits. 50+ CIMMYT maize hybrids have been licensed to public and private partners (2015-2020) for release. By 2020, farmers had adopted 16 varieties on over 20,000 ha.

title_oics: The European Union includes agricultural landscape biodiversity targets in its Green Deal strategies and in preparation for the Convention on Biological Diversity
title_project: Development of toolkit and WLE Decision Framework.
outcome_impact_statement: The European Union, as part of its Farm to Fork Strategy and Biodiversity Strategy for 2030, is proposing 10% conservation of natural and semi-natural habitats in agricultural landscapes. WLE researchers contributed significantly to this proposal through their research and engagement with the European Union.

title_oics: Guidance and management techniques help to combat and recover from Fall ArmyWorm in West and Central Africa
title_project: Fall Army Worm (FAW) Response
outcome_impact_statement: On the basis of a comprehensive integrated pest management (IPM) approach to control fall armyworm (FAW; spodoptera frugiperda), MAIZE convened west and central African partners, who incorporated the approach in policy & extension systems. It focuses on the use of 6 promising indigenous parasitoids and screening of different chemical pesticides, biopesticides and botanicals. Under good agronomic management, their use led to good maize recovery. Promising synthetic varieties have been developed and currently tested in on-farm trials to fast-track their commercialization.

title_oics: Accelerating the rate of genetic value creation for East and South African smallholder maize farmers
title_project: Refinement and deployment of a dynamic training set method to improve GS prediction using historic data
outcome_impact_statement: Maize breeding creates value for farmers by delivering varieties which provide stable and improved harvests.  The MAIZE breeding team adapted genomic technologies to improve the efficiency of the breeding process, to deliver more value to African small holder maize farmers per unit of investment, by reducing the cost of first year field evaluation by 40%. Current and future innovations applying genomic technology to breeding pipelines will increase CGIAR and eastern and southern African maize breeding programs' precision and efficiency.

title_oics: CCAFS Investment-Oriented Outcome Pathways: Lessons and New Directions
title_project: [Flagship Leader] FP1: Engagement, synthesis and support

title_oics: Impact assessment of CCAFS support to the 7th Five Year Plan in Bangladesh
title_project: [Flagship Leader] FP1: Engagement, synthesis and support

title_oics: Landscape Analysis of Financial Flows (LAFF): An inclusive method analyzing investment flows informs multi-stakeholders action plans and investment decision-making for sustainable development and resilient landscapes
title_project: 17.  Innovating finance for sustainable landscapes
outcome_impact_statement: Tropenbos International (TBI) and EcoAgriculture Partners developed a participatory Landscape Analysis of Financial Flows (LAFF) method for multi-stakeholder partnerships (MSP) or individual actors (e.g., governments, non-governmental organizations, civil society organizations) seeking to advance sustainable landscape investments. The LAFF method helps participants develop a shared understanding of the landscape economy, identifying investment gaps and opportunities to meet locally-prioritized development objectives. LAFF has influenced policy, action plans, and investment decision-making in Ghana, Indonesia and Vietnam to support sustainability, climate action, and livelihoods.

title_oics: Tools for farmers to policy makers to mainstream biodiversity for food and nutrition in local food systems: examples from Brazil, Kenya, Sri Lanka and Turkey
title_project: Policy process analysis and policy engagement
scope_comments: The potential reach for the resources is global, although the work was originally focused in Brazil, Kenya, Sri Lanka, and Turkey.
outcome_impact_statement: The Biodiversity for Food and Nutrition (BFN) project pioneered an innovative approach to prioritization, research and promotion of biodiversity for food security and nutrition. Part of the project’s legacy has been the development of free, online resources that help others interested in promoting local biodiversity for improved nutrition. In addition, ongoing collaboration continues with international agencies and country-level partners to incorporate tools in relevant sectoral programmes and strategies and carry forward the positive momentum.

title_oics: A Paradigm Shift in Government Initiatives on Dairy and Pork Quality and Safety in Informal Markets in Assam, India
title_project: Technological and institutional innovations for assessing, communicating and mitigating food safety risks designed and tested, with capacity building (Product Lines)
scope_comments: Although the activities are being scaling out in 16 project district of Assam but the initiative will benefit all the project districts of the state (total 34).
outcome_impact_statement: Results from a promising food safety intervention designed and tested by CGIAR combined with long-term engagement with the Government of Assam have led to changes in the government's posture towards the informal dairy and pork sectors. The World Bank and the Government of Assam in India are scaling a food safety intervention designed and tested by ILRI in informal dairy value chains in 16 districts and in informal pork value chains in 13 districts, expected to benefit millions of consumers.

title_oics: Mitigating production risk through stress tolerant varieties may be more appealing than index-insurance to Northern Nigerian farmers
title_project: Conduct study on improving  financial inclusion of smallholder farmers in Nigeria.

title_oics: Conservation agriculture and precision nutrient management in South Asia maize-based systems provide mitigation benefits and more food and economic benefits to smallholders
title_project: USAID- Cereal Systems Initiative for South Asia- Phase III

title_oics: Cost Advantage of Biofortified Maize for the Poultry Feed Industry and Its Implications for Value Chain Actors in Nepal
title_project: Nepal Seed and Fertilizer (NSAF)

title_oics: An assessment of the Diversity for Restoration (D4R) Tool.
title_project: 1.  Restoration (forest and landscape restoration)

title_oics: ShadeMotion: Applications of an open-source canopy shade-modelling software in post-secondary curricula, short-term training workshops, and demonstration farms across Latin America for climate-resilient agroforestry practice
title_project: 2.  Plantations and tree crop commodities
scope_comments: Some indications of global awareness of the innovation can be gleaned from Google Analytics: for example, the top ten countries’ visitors to the shademotion.net website originate from Colombia, Costa Rica, USA, Brazil, Spain, Guatemala, Peru, Mexico, Honduras, and Argentina.
outcome_impact_statement: The Tropical Agricultural Research and Higher Education Center’s (CATIE) ShadeMotion innovation is an open-source technology that models tree shade and can inform tree-planting practices to improve crop yields, enhance agroforest sustainability, and support climate adaptation of both farm and agro-ecosystems. ShadeMotion is intended for use by researchers (including students), farmers, and practitioners (e.g., extension staff, technicians). Integration of ShadeMotion in post-secondary curricula, training, and application in demonstration farms in Latin America supports capacity development and more sustainable agroforestry practices.

title_oics: Greater Integration of the Environmental Sector in CGIAR's One Health Activities Following the Emergence and Global Spread of the Novel Coronavirus Called SARS-CoV-2
title_project: Evidence that counts for zoonoses
outcome_impact_statement: Origins of recent zoonotic epidemics link the research themes of human, animal and environmental health: the three tenets of One Health. Within CGIAR, the environmental sector has not been fully integrated into One Health. In 2020, a major report, Preventing the Next Pandemic argued for better ways of achieving trans-disciplinarity in One Health. The report, alongside targeted CGIAR communication around One Health, has resulted in more partnerships with environmental institutions and a strengthened CGIAR influence in One Health.

title_oics: Funder Requests A4NH Inputs into the Direction of a Major Development Investment Strategy to Mitigate any Unintended Negative Consequences on Human Health in West Africa
title_project: Evidence base on farming and environment practices that reduce health risks
outcome_impact_statement: In Africa, a child dies of malaria every two minutes. Ricefields are an important breeding place for mosquitoes. Recent work by A4NH has confirmed that the introduction of rice brings more malaria to local residents; hence rice intensification may be an obstacle to malaria elimination. In 2020, a meeting was convened to bring together Japanese agronomists and health experts to discuss the implications of A4NH research for their plans to support a major expansion of irrigated rice in Africa.

title_oics: Monitoring survey for iron beans and vitamin A maize in Zimbabwe
title_project: Monitoring and learning for biofortification

title_oics: Integration of the Kaleidoscope Model of Policy Change in the Master’s degree program in Agricultural and Applied Economics at the University of Pretoria, South Africa
title_project: 2.3.1 Drivers of Agricultural Policy Reforms
scope_comments: The students who were part of the Masters program were from 11 African countries., which suggests potential spillovers outside of South Africa.
outcome_impact_statement: The Kaleidoscope Model, a tool that can be used by researchers, practitioners and donors to identify entry points for improving the likelihood of policy change, was included in the curriculum of the Master’s degree in Agricultural and Applied Economics at the University of Pretoria, South Africa. In 2020, 30 students from 11 African countries were trained in the use of the Kaleidoscope Model through this program.

title_oics: Evidence-based support for integration of Quality Declared Seeds (QDS) in Uganda's new seed policy, with 2,000 farmers already trained in the production of QDS
title_project: 1.2.1 Seeds Systems and Markets
outcome_impact_statement: As recommended by a PIM study, Uganda's new seed policy introduces Quality Declared Seeds (QDS) - a new class of local seed produced by farmers and community seed banks with less costly provisions for quality assurance, allowing farmers to commercialize popular varieties at the local level and thus improving access to quality seeds. Two community seedbanks are already QDS certified and five have started the certification process. 2,000 farmers were trained in the production of QDS in 2020,

title_oics: PIM research used to develop school gardens in 29 schools for better nutrition of 28,000 students in Papua New Guinea
title_project: 2.4.8 Other Policy Engagement
outcome_impact_statement: Through a collaboration with the Government of Papua New Guinea, the Australia Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and several other partners, data and analyses on household nutrition collected by IFPRI were used to provide insights for launching the Morobe School Gardens Project, aiming at improving nutrition of 28,000 schoolchildren in 29 schools. In November 2020, the Papua New Guinea National Education Board passed a resolution to scale up school gardens across the country.

title_oics: Informing the Government of South Africa’s projections on the economic effects of the COVID-19 pandemic
title_project: 2.1.4 Rural-Urban Linkages and Agri-Food System Employment
outcome_impact_statement: Research on the impact of the initial nationwide COVID-19 lockdown on the South African economy carried out by an IFPRI-led team under the banner of the Southern Africa-Towards Inclusive Economic Development (SA-TIED) program informed the Government of South Africa’s projections on the economic effects of the pandemic and was used by the South African Reserve Bank and National Treasury to adjust their macroeconomic forecasts.

title_oics: Registration of eleven local varieties of rice and beans distributed by more than 3,000 farmers in Nepal
title_project: 1.2.1 Seeds Systems and Markets
outcome_impact_statement: With PIM support, Bioversity International and partners provided technical and policy support for the registration process for local varieties in Nepal and assisted farmers' associations in submitting registration proposals, leading to registration of eleven varieties of rice and beans. 3,000 farmers and eight farmers’ cooperatives are already engaged in the distribution of these varieties, generating enhanced benefits for farming communities and increased crop diversity.

title_oics: The Government of Uganda adopts PIM recommendations to improve a nationwide program aimed at involving citizens towards effective public service delivery
title_project: 2.4.8 Other Policy Engagement
outcome_impact_statement: PIM researchers conducted an impact evaluation of the Baraza program, which has been implemented by the Office of the Prime Minister since 2009 to improve public services. The findings and recommendations of the study are being used to increase the program’s cost-effectiveness and inclusivity, potentially affecting millions of citizens throughout the country.

title_oics: HarvestPlus-led Delivery Efforts Resulted in an Estimated 48.5 Million People Consuming Biofortified Crops in 2020
title_project: Monitoring and learning for biofortification
scope_comments:
Information by country is available here: https://www.harvestplus.org/where-we-work
HarvestPlus works with more than 600 partners, listed here: https://www.harvestplus.org/about/our-partners
outcome_impact_statement: HarvestPlus leads the development and delivery of biofortified crops, and the research on their efficacy, effectiveness, acceptability and adoption. By the end of 2020, 393 biofortified varieties of 12 staple crops were approved for planting in 41 countries, and an estimated 9.7 million farming households (48.5 million people) were growing and consuming biofortified crops across 19 countries Africa, Asia, and Latin America. Consumption of biofortified crops are proven to improve not only nutrition and health, but also other livelihood outcomes.

title_oics: itamin A Orange sweet potato and Iron beans grown and consumed respectively by 960,000 and 695,000 households in Uganda
title_project: Monitoring and learning for biofortification
outcome_impact_statement: 2020 marked 15 years of HarvestPlus activities in Uganda. The latest monitoring data shows that 960,000 smallholder households – more than 10% of the Ugandan population – were growing vitamin A orange sweet potato (OSP) varieties and 695,000 households were growing iron beans. Ensuring the supply of clean planting material, payback and pay forward delivery systems, digital technologies, and a multi-stakeholder technical working group are some of the innovative approaches that have been used successfully to sustain and scale-up biofortification.

title_oics: Stories of Change Case Study Approach Used to Support Nutrition Policy Decisions in Rwanda: Successful Advocacy at Local and District Level
title_project: Evidence on enabling environments, effective decision making processes and impacts of nutrition-sensitive agricultural policies
outcome_impact_statement: Stories of Change is a structured case study approach which systematically assesses and analyzes drivers of nutritional change in specific country contexts. These resulting ‘stories’ improve our understanding of what drives impact in reducing undernutrition, and how enabling environments and pro-nutrition policy and implementation processes can be cultivated and sustained. The Story of Change case study approach in Rwanda resulted in a better understanding of the national drivers of change in nutrition and recommendations for future improvements.

title_oics: Findings from the Myanmar Agriculture Policy Support Activity inform the Government of Myanmar’s response to the COVID-19 pandemic
title_project: 2.4.9 Support to Myanmar Policies
outcome_impact_statement: Research conducted under the Myanmar Agriculture Policy Support Activity – led by IFPRI in partnership with Michigan State University and funded by USAID with support from PIM – informed the government’s response to the COVID-19 pandemic and contributed to the decision of the Myanmar Agriculture Development Bank to invest USD 430M in loans to farmers.

title_oics: Deployment of PIM guidance on development of multi-actor platforms for landscape governance and restoration across six states in India
title_project: 5.2.1 Governing Shared Landscapes
outcome_impact_statement: With support from PIM, Collaborating for Resilience worked with Foundation for Ecological Security (FES) to develop guidance and train FES field teams on development of multi-actor platforms for landscape-level governance and restoration efforts in India. The guidance has been adopted as an integral part of Foundation for Ecological Security’s program implementation across six states (Andhra Pradesh, Gujarat, Karnataka, Odisha, Rajasthan and Uttar Pradesh).

title_oics: Contribution to Malawi's National Agricultural Extension and Advisory Services Strategy, launched in 2020 to guide investments
title_project: 1.2.2 Agricultural Extension and Advisory Services
outcome_impact_statement: In December 2020, the Government of Malawi launched the National Agricultural Extension and Advisory Services Strategy (NAEASS), a document aimed at guiding the country’s agricultural extension investments in the next five years. This strategy is the outcome of over two years of stakeholder consultations and review in which IFPRI was heavily involved. PIM-supported IFPRI research is cited in several documents pertaining to the development of the policy and in draft versions of the NAEASS itself.

title_oics: Rehabilitation of dry agro-pastures through community-based mechanized micro water harvesting and flood-irrigation agriculture to benefit to 1,000 ha/ year in Jordan
title_project: Lessons learnt from on-farm to watershed level interventions: out-scaling of community based watershed management strategies to diverse socio-ecological environment
scope_comments: The mechanized community-driven micro water harvesting approach was tested in Syria.
outcome_impact_statement: Mechanized micro-water harvesting packages developed by ICARDA and the Jordanian National Agricultural Research Center (NARC) are being scaled out in collaboration with local communities, targeting at least 1,000 hectares per year and 20,000 km2 in the long term. The community-based approach effectively rehabilitates degraded dry agro-pastoral watersheds through water harvesting, plantation of native vegetation, and enhanced downstream flood-water agriculture. Community empowerment ensures long-term sustainability of the interventions. The program is expected to equip communities better for drought conditions while improving carbon storage in the uplands and reducing the need for agricultural inputs in the lowlands.

title_oics: Assessing the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and formulating policy responses to protect vulnerable sectors and populations in Rwanda
title_project: 2.4.10 Support to Rwanda Policies
outcome_impact_statement: Using PIM economic policy modelling tools, IFPRI provided strategic and timely advice to the Government of Rwanda to assess the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and of the measures taken to control its spread, implement short-term policy responses to protect vulnerable sectors and populations and formulate longer-term policies to spur economic recovery.

title_oics: Wheat Varietal Diversiﬁcation Increases Ethiopian Smallholders’ Food Security for 50,000 to 75,000 farmers: Evidence from a WLE/Alliance-led Participatory Development Initiative
title_project: Using biodiversity, including genetic diversity, for land restoration
outcome_impact_statement: The WLE/Alliance-led Seeds for Needs program developed a new way to evaluate and promote improved seed varieties, and advanced breeding lines. A survey of 1008 households across three Ethiopian states shows the program signiﬁcantly enhanced wheat productivity and smallholders’ food security by increasing varietal diversiﬁcation. The study provides empirical evidence for the effective role varietal diversity can play in improving food security in marginal environments.

title_oics: Impact of Girinka program on child nutritional status and household food security
title_project: Product Line 5.3.1: Menu of approaches for nutrition-sensitive livestock-related interventions to improve availability, affordability, access and utilization of animal-source foods

title_oics: Evidence-based support to change the modalities of Egypt's food subsidy system for better effectiveness and improved nutrition and food security impacts
title_project: 2.4.7 MENA Regional Policy Engagement
outcome_impact_statement: Since 2012, PIM has provided support to the longstanding partnership between IFPRI and the Government of Egypt to reform the country’s food subsidy system for better effectiveness and improved nutrition and food security impacts. The most recent round of reform is ongoing and aims at better targeting the system’s beneficiaries.

title_oics: Projections of the impacts of COVID-19 on the Egyptian economy based on PIM modeling tools informed the Government of Egypt’s responses to the pandemic
title_project: 2.4.7 MENA Regional Policy Engagement
outcome_impact_statement: Egypt’s Ministry of Planning and Economic Development requested support from IFPRI to quantify the expected national and sectoral impacts of the pandemic on the Egyptian economy and investigate the consequences of various policy interventions in mitigating the disruptive effects of the virus. This collaboration was based on the use of PIM modeling tools. The results informed the Government’s responses to the pandemic.

title_oics: Outcome evaluation of climate-smart research on solar-powered irrigation in India conducted under the WLE, CCAFS and SMO
title_project: On & off-grid Solar in Africa and Asia

title_oics: CGIAR Research Program 2020 Reviews: Water, Land and Ecosystems
title_project: WLE Program Management Unit

title_oics: Outcome evaluation of climate-smart research on solar-powered irrigation in India
title_project: Scaling-up Strategies for Climate Risk Management in South Asian Agriculture

title_oics: Adoption of "How are we doing?" tool by the Peruvian Service for Natural Protected Areas to enable more equitable co-management of 76 protected areas covering 15% of Peru’s territory.
title_project: 9. Landscape Governance
outcome_impact_statement: CIFOR collaborated with multi-stakeholder fora in Peru and Indonesia to develop a tool that allows participants to monitor and reflect on the processes and progress of their fora so that more equitable processes and outcomes may emerge. Partnering with Peru’s Service for Natural Protected Areas, CIFOR adapted this tool for annual implementation by the multi-stakeholder Management Committees of 76 protected areas covering 15% of Peru’s territory.

title_oics: Over 11,000 households benefit from bamboo bioenergy across Africa and Indonesia, via support from the International Network for Bamboo and Rattan (INBAR) for women-led bamboo enterprises, sustainable livelihoods, and land restoration
title_project: 6.  Bioenergy an essential part of low-emissions development strategies and policies
scope_comments: India is another project site. Some indication of potential scale out of bamboo’s potential for bioenergy to Kenya, Uganda, and Cameroon
outcome_impact_statement: The International Network for Bamboo and Rattan (INBAR) in close collaboration with FTA partners led and transferred research on bamboo bioenergy production technologies and smallholder bamboo value chains across Africa and Asia. Related projects raised awareness and influenced households to plant bamboo on farms and degraded lands to improve rural livelihoods, targeting women and youth. Adoption of bamboo-planting across Africa and Southeast Asian countries is expected to decrease deforestation and support land restoration.

title_oics: Use of global forests dynamics monitoring database and form recommendations for sustainable management by the Tropical Managed Forest Observatory Network
title_project: 1.  Restoration (forest and landscape restoration)
scope_comments: Amazon, Central and West Africa, South East Asia (analyses possible at regional and pantropical levels)
outcome_impact_statement: The Tropical Managed Forest Observatory Network (TmFO) monitors the dynamics of tropical logged forests around the world to develop new evidence-based logging practices that maintain long-term forest functions for ecosystem functioning and economic viability. TmFO brings new paradigms for management of forests, particularly in the Amazon, demonstrates caveats in selective logging rules to inform sustainable transitions, and creates the basis for collective action on sustainable and profitable forest management over the long term.

title_oics: Farmer-to-farmer training adopted by 86 organizations serving 352,000 farmers in Eastern Africa improves dairy farmers' knowledge, productivity and revenues
title_project: 3. Enhanced nutrition and food security
outcome_impact_statement: Since 2012, FTA and PIM have supported efforts by ICRAF and partners to implement the volunteer farmer trainer approach in Eastern Africa. As of 2018, 86 organizations across Eastern Africa have adopted the volunteer farmer trainer approach. These organizations work with 17,600 volunteer farmer trainers and serve 352,000 farmers. An impact evaluation found that the use of this approach improved farmers? knowledge of dairy practices as well as dairy productivity and revenues in Uganda's Busoga region.

title_oics: FTA's proposals integrated in the newly endorsed Voluntary Guidelines on Food Systems and Nutrition of the United Nations Committee on World Food Security (CFS)
title_project: 3. Enhanced nutrition and food security
outcome_impact_statement: The Committee on World Food Security (CFS) has endorsed the first-ever Voluntary Guidelines on Food Systems and Nutrition (VGFSyN) which aim to support countries to eradicate hunger and malnutrition in all its forms by utilizing a food systems approach. FTA had an active role in the multi-stakeholder process that led to the approval of the guidelines.

title_oics: Improved Son tra (Docynia indica) varieties and propagation techniques to increase production  and income for potentially 123,000-247,000 households in Northwest Vietnam.
title_project: 3. Enhanced nutrition and food security
outcome_impact_statement: Domestication of indigenous Son tra or H’mong apple fruits has resulted in higher yields of superior, more marketable fruits while helping in soil conservation efforts in the North-West region of Vietnam. FTA supported partnerships, helped develop and scale adoption of superior son tra genotypes by smallholder farmers and government-led land restoration initiatives. This has contributed to improved son tra yields, increased farmer income, improved soil erosion control measures, agro-biodiversity improvements, carbon sequestration and landscape resilience through locally suited agroforestry models.

title_oics: Mid-Term Review of the Provision of Adequate Tree Seed Portfolios Projects
title_project: 1.  Restoration (forest and landscape restoration)

title_oics: Integration Study to assess the contribution of the Forests, Trees and Agroforestry CGIAR Research Program to improving food and nutritional security
title_project: 21. Quality of FTA research for development

title_oics: An Outcome Evaluation of FTA’s Research Portfolio on Oil Palm
title_project: 21. Quality of FTA research for development

title_oics: Global Comparative Study of REDD+ (GCS REDD+) Endterm Review
title_project: 5.  NDCs - the central mechanism for climate policy under the Paris Agreement

title_oics: Integration Study to assess FTA Contribution to the protection of forests and reduction of deforestation
title_project: 21. Quality of FTA research for development

title_oics: Understanding and evaluating the impact of integrated problem-oriented research programmes: Concepts and considerations
title_project: 21. Quality of FTA research for development

title_oics: External technical reviews and validation of quality management systems (QMS)
Costing reviews of CGIAR genebanks
System level review of genebank costs and operations (GCO)
Document audits of Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs)
Genebank Impacts Fellowship
Kenya launches a Bioenergy Strategy supported by World Agroforestry
title_project: 6.  Bioenergy an essential part of low-emissions development strategies and policies
outcome_impact_statement: The African nation is pushing ahead with an ambitious goal to optimize use of bioenergy, supported by World Agroforestry (ICRAF).

title_oics: Gender research in the CGIAR Research Program on Policies, Institutions, and Markets in 2018 and 2019
title_project: 6.2.1 Analysis of and Support to Integrative Gender Research in other PIM Flagships

title_oics: Technological innovation and sustainable intensification: Highlights, lessons learned, and priorities for One CGIAR
title_project: 1.0.1 Flagship 1 Management (Flagship Leaders and Cluster Leaders)

title_oics: Social protection for agriculture and resilience: Highlights, lessons learned, and priorities for One CGIAR
title_project: 4.0.1 Flagship 4 Management (Flagship Leaders and Cluster Leaders)
